titleStmt.title: May-day. A vvitty comedie, diuers times acted at the Blacke Fryers. VVritten by George Chapman.

div.p: MAY-DAY. A witty Comedie, diuers times acted at the Blacke Fryers.
LONDON. Printed for Iohn Browne; dwelling in Fleetstreete in Saint Dunstones Church-yard. 1611.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Interim, Intrat Lorenzo, Papers in his hand.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
WEll done my lusty bloods, Well done. Fit, fit obseruance for this May-morning; Not the May-Moneth alone, they take when it comes; Nor the first weeke of that Moneth; Nor the first day; but the first minute of the first houre, of the first day. Loose no time bloods, loose no time; though the Sunne goe to bedde neuer so much before you, yet be you vp before him; call the golden sluggard from the siluer armes of his Lady, to light you into yours, when your old father Ianuary here in one of his last dayes, thrusts his fore-head into the depth of Mayes fragrant bosome: What may you Aprilles performe then? O what may you doe? Well yet will I say thus much for my selfe, wheresoeuer the affections of youth are, there must needs be the instruments, and where the instruments are, there must of necessity be the faculties; What am I short of them then? A sound old man, ably constituted, holsomly dyeted, that tooke his May
temperately at their ages, and continued his owne; why should he not continue their ages in his owne? By the Masse I feele nothing that stands against it, and therefore sweet May I salute thee with the yongest: I haue loue to employ thee in, as well as the prowdest yong princock, and so haue at you Mistris Frances China: haue at you Mistris Franke: I'le sprede my nets for you yfaith, though they be my very purse nets, wherein what heart will not willingly lye panting? (Enter Angelo.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now? Gods my life, I wonder what made this May-morning so cold, and now I see 'tis this Ianuary that intrudes into it; what paper is that he holds in hand trow we?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Here haue I put her face in rime, but I feare my old vaine will not stretch to her contentment. O haire, no haire but beames stolne from the Sunne.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Out vpon her, if it be shee that I thinke, shee has a Fox red cranion;

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A fore-head that disdaines the name of faire.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And reason, for 'tis a folwe one.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A matchlesse eye.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: True, her eyes be not matches.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A cheeke, vermillion red.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Painted I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A farre commanding mouth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It stretches to her eares in deede.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A nose made out of waxe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A red nose, in sincerity.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This could I send, but person, person does it: A good presence, to beare out a good wit; a good face, a prety Court legge, and a deft dapper personage, no superfluous dimensions, but fluent in competence; for it is not Hector but Paris, not the full armefull, but the sweet handfull that Ladies delight in.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O notable old whyniard.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Such a size of humanity now, and braine enough
in it, it is not in the strength of a woman to withstand; well shee may hold out a parlee or two, for 'tis a weake fort that obeyes at the first or second summons, if shee resist the third shee is discharg'd, though shee yeeld in future: for then it appeares it was no fault of hers: but the man that would take no deniall. What rests now? meanes for accesse: True. O an honest Baude were worth gold now.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A plague vpon him, I had thought to haue appear'd to him, but now if I doe, he will take me for the man he talks on: I will therefore post by his dull eye-sight, as in hast of businesse.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What Signior Angelo? soft I command you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Gods precious, what meane you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I would be loth to be out-runne I assure you Sir: was I able to stay you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Your ability stood too stiffe Sir, beshrow me else.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O most offencelesse fault, I would thou would'st blaze my imperfection to one thou know'st, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well Sir another time, tell me where shee is, and Ile doe so much for you gratis. Good morrow Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nay stay good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: My businesse sayes nay Sir, you haue made me stay to my paine Sir, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Not a whit man I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Goe to then, briefly, to whom shall I commend your imperfections, will you tell me if I name her?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: That I will, yfaith Boy.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Is not her haire, no haire, but beames stolne from the Sunne?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Blacke, blacke as an Ouzell.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A fore-head that disdaines the name of faire.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Away Witch, away:

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A matchlesse eye.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Nay fie, fie, fie. I see th'art a very Deuill Angelo. And in earnest, I iested, when I said my desire of thy friendship touch'd my selfe, for it concernes a friend of mine iust
of my standing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: To whom then would he be remembred that I can sollicite?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To sweet Mistris Franciscina: with whom I heare thou art ready to lye downe, thou art so great with her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am as great as a neare Kinseman may be with her Sir, not otherwise:

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A good consanguinity: and good Angelo, to her with thou deliuer from my friend, in all secrecy, these poore brace of bracelets?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Perhaps I will Sir, when I know what the Gentleman and his intent is.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Neuer examine that man; I would not trouble you with carrying too much at once to her, only tell her, such a man will resolue her, naming me: and I doe not greatly care, if I take the paines to come to her, so I stay not long, and be let in priuily: and so without making many wordes: here they be, put them vp closely I beseech thee, and deliuer them as closely.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well Sir, I loue no contention with friends, and therefore pocket many things, that otherwise I would not: but I pray Sir licence me a question. Doe not I know this Gentleman that offers my Cozen this kindnesse?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Neuer saw'st him in thy life, at least neuer knew'st him; but for his bounty sake to all his well willers, if this message be friendly discharged, I may chance put a deare friend of him into your bosome: Sir, and make you profitably acquainted.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: But I pray you Sir, is he not a well elderly Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Wide, wide; as yong as day, I protest to thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know he is yong too, but that is in ability of body, but is he not a prety little squat Gentleman, as you shall see amongst a thousand?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Still from the cushion, still, tall and high, like a Cedar.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know he is tall also, but it is in his minde Sir, and it is not Hector but Paris, not thy full armefull, but the sweet handfull that a Lady delights to dandle.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now the good Deuill take thee, if there be any such in hell, hell I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well, well Signior Lorenzo, yfaith the litle Squire is thought to be as parlesse a peece of flesh, for a peece of flesh, as any hunts the hole pale of Venus I protest t'ee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I cannot containe my selfe, yfaith Boy, if the Wenches come in my walke, I giue 'em that they come for, I dally not with hem.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know you doe not Sir, his dallying dayes be done.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It is my infirmity, and I cannot doe withall, to die for't.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I beleeue you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: There are certaine enuious old fellowes, my neighbours, that say, I am one vnwieldly and stiffe: Angelo, didst euer heare any wench complaine of my stiffenesse?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Neuer in my life: your old neighbours measure you by themselues.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why ther's the matter then?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: But yfaith Sir: doe you euer hope to winne your purpose at my losing hands, knowing her (as all the world does) a woman of that approued lowlynesse of life, and so generally tryed?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: As for that take thou no care, shee's a woman, is shee not?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sure I doe take her to haue the flesh and blood of a woman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Then good enough, or then bad enough, this token shall be my Gentleman Vsher to prepare my accesse, and then let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I marry Sir, I thinke you would be alone with her; Well Sir, I will doe my best, but if your Gentleman Vsher should not get entrance for you now, it would be a griefe
to me. (Enter Gasparo an old Clowne.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Feare it not man: Gifts and gold, take the strong'st hold; Away, here comes a snudge that must be my sonne in law: I would be loth he should suspect these tricks of youth in me, for feare he feare my daughter will trot after me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Godge you God morrow Sir, godge you God morrow.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: God morrow neighbour Gasparo: I haue talk't with my daughter, whom I doe yet finde a greene yong plant, and therefore vnapt to beare such ripe fruit, I thinke I might haue said rotten, as your selfe: But shee is at my disposition, and shall be at yours in the end, here's my hand, and with my hand take hers.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Nay by my faith Sir, you must giue me leaue to shake her portion by the hand first.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It is ready told for you Sir, come home when you will and receiue it, (Enter Aemilia. )and see, yonder shee comes; away, shee cannot yet abide you, because shee feares shee can abide you too well.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, I will come for her potion Sir, and till then, God take you to his mercy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Adiew my good sonne in law, Ile not interrupt her, let her meditate a my late motion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.l: 'Tis strange to see the impiety of parents,
Both priuiledgd by custome, and profest,
The holy institution of heauen;
Ordeyning marriage for proportiond minds,
For our chiefe humane comforts; and t'encrease
The loued images of God in men:
Is now peruerted to th'increase of wealth;
We must bring riches forth, and like the Cuckoe
Hatch others egges; Ioyne house to house, in choices
Fit timber-logs and stones, not men and women: (Enter Aurelio.)
Ay me, here's one I must shunne, woude embrace. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O stay and heare me speake or see me dye. (Enter Lodouico and Giacono.)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now? what haue we here? what a loathsome creature man is being drunke: Is it not pitty to see a man of good hope, a toward Scholler, writes a theame well, scannes a verse very well, and likely in time to make a proper man, a good legge, specially in a boote, valiant, well spoken, and in a word, what not? and yet all this ouerthrowne as you see, drownd, quite drownd in a quarte pott.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: O these same wicked healths, breede monstrous diseases.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aurelio, speake man, Aurelio?

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Pray heauen all be well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O speake, if any sparke of speech remaine.
It is thy deare Aemilia that calles.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, well, it becomes not a friend to touch the deadly wounds of his friend with a smiling countenance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Touch thee? sblood I could finde in my heart to beate thee; vp in a fooles name, vp: what a Scene of foppery haue we here?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Prethee haue done.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Vp Cuckoe Cupids bird, or by this light Ile fetch thy father to thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Good Lodouico, if thou lou'st me, leaue me; thou com'st to consaile me from that, which is ioynd with my soule in eternity: I must and will doe what I doe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Doe so then, and I protest thou shalt neuer licke thy lips after my Kinsewoman, while thou liu'st: I had thought to haue spoken for thee, if thou hadst taken a manly course with her: but to fold vp thy selfe like an Vrchine, and lye a caluing to bring forth a husband: I am asham'd to thinke on't: sblood I haue heard of wenches that haue been wonne with singing and dancing, and some with riding, but neuer heard of any that was wonne with tumbling in my life.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: If thou knew'st how vaine thou seem'st.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I doe it of purpose, to shew how vaine I hold thy disease, S'hart art thou the first that has shot at a wenches heart and mist it? must that shot that mist her wound thee? let her shake her heeles in a shrowes name: were shee my Cozen a thousand times, and if I were as thee, I would make her shake her heeles too, afore I would shake mine thus.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O vanity, vanity.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: S'death, if any wench should offer to keepe possession of my heart against my will, I'de fire her out with Sacke and Sugar, or smoke her out with Tobacko, like a hornet, or purge for her, for loue is but a humor: one way or other I would vent her, thats infallible.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For shame hold thy tongue, me thinks thy wit should feele how stale are these loue stormes, and with what generall priuiledge loue pierses the worthiest. Seeke to help thy friend, not mocke him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry, seeke to helpe thy selfe then, in a halters name, doe not lie in a ditch, and say God helpe me, vse the lawfull tooles he hath lent thee. Vp I say I will bring thee to her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Shee'll not endure me:

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Shee shall endure thee doe the worst thou canst to her, I and endure thee till thou canst not endure her; But then thou must vse thy selfe like a man, and a wise man, how deepe soeuer shee is in thy thoughts, carry not the prints of it in thy lookes; be bold and carelesse, and stand not sautring a farre of, as I haue seene you, like a Dogge in a firmetypot, that licks his chops and wags his taile, and faine would lay his lips to it, but he feares tis too hot for him: thats the only way to make her too hot for thee. He that holds religious and sacred thought of a woman, he that beares so reuerend a respect to her, that he will not touch her but with a kist hand and a timorous heart; he that adores her like his Goddesse: Let him be sure shee will shunne him like her slaue. Alas good soules, women of themselues are tractable and tactable enough, and would returne Quid for
Quod still, but we are they that spoile'em, and we shall answere for't another day. We are they that put a kind of wanton Melancholie into 'em, that makes 'em thinke their noses bigger then their faces, greater then the Sunne in brightnesse; and where as Nature made 'em but halfe fooles, we make 'em all foole. And this is our palpable flattery of them, where they had rather haue plaine dealing Well, in conclusion, Ile to her instantly, and if I doe not bring her to thee, or at the least some speciall fauour from her, as a feather from her fanne, or a string from her shoo, to weare in thy hat, and so forth, then neuer trust my skill in poultry whilst thou liu'st againe. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Quintiliano, A purse of twenty pound in gold. Innocentio, Fransischina, Angelo, and Fannio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: THou shalt not to the warres, or if thou do'st Ile beare thee company, deare Quint. doe not offer to forsake me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Hands off wife, hang not vpon me thus; how can I maintaine thee but by vsing my valour? and how can I vse that, but in action and employment? goe in, play at cardes with your Cozen Angelo here, and let it suffise I loue thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come sweet Cozen, doe not cloy your husband with your loue so, especially to hinder his preferment; who shall the Duke haue to employ in these Marshall necessities if not Captaine Quintiliano, he beares an honorable minde, and tis pitty but he should haue employment. Let him get a company now, and he will be able to maintaine you like a Duches hereafter.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Well said Signior Angelo, gossaue me you speake like a true Cozen indeede, does he not Quint?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: He does so, and I thanke him; yet see how the foole puts finger ith' eye still.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Ile cheere her vp, I warrant you Captaine; come
Cuze, lets in to tables.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Farewell sweet Mistris.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Farewell my good seruant.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now take away thy hand, and show thou didst laugh all this while; good Lord who would not marry to haue so kinde a wife make much on him? Exit.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: After Boy, giue your attendance.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Could you not spare me money for mine hostesse, where you put me to boarde? y'are a whole fortnight arrerages.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Attend I say, the hostes of the Lyon has a legge like a Gyant, want for nothing Boy, so shee score truly.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Faith Sir, shee has chaulk't vp twenty shillings already, and sweares shee will chaulke no more.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then let her choke, and choke thou with her: S'blood hobby horse, and she had chaulkt vp twenty pounds, I hope the world knowes I am able to pay it with a wet finger.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I thinke y'are able, but the world does not know it.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then the worlds an ignorant Sir, and you are an innocent, vanish Boy, away.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: I hope he will foist some money for my score, out of this gull here. Exit.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: 'Tis a plaguy good wagge Quint. ist not?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Ile make him a good one 'ere I ha done with him; but this same louing foole my wife now, will neuer leaue weeping, till I make her beleeue I will not haue a company. Who would be combred with these soft hearted creatures, that are euer in extreames, either too kinde, or too vnkind?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Saue me, 'tis true, 'tis a hard thing must please'em in sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Damne me, if I doe not pitty her with my heart; plague on her kindnesse, she has halfe perswaded me to take no company.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Nay sweet Quint: then how shall I be a Lieftenant?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well, and my promise were not past to thee, I am a villaine if all the world should part Franke and me; thinke I loue thee therefore, and will doe thee credit: It will cost me a great deale a this same foolish money to buy me drum and ensigne, and furnish me throughly, but the best is I know my credit.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Sfut Quint, wee'll want no money man, Ile make my row of houses flie first.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Let'em walke, let'em walke; Candle rents: if the warres hold, or a plague come to the towne, theill be worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: True, or while I am beyond Sea, some sleepy wench may set fire ith bed-straw.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Right, or there may come an earthquake, and ouerturne'em.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Iust, or there may be coniuring, and the winde may downe with'em.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Or some crafty petty-fogger may finde a hole in the title, a thousand casualties belongs to 'em.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Nay, they shall walke, thats certaine, Ile turne 'em into money.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thats thy most husbandly course yfaith Boy, thou maist haue twenty ith' hundred for thy life, Ile be thy man for two hundred.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Wil't yfaith Quint? gossaue me tis done.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: For your life, not otherwise.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Well, I desire no more, so you'll remember me for my Lieftenantship.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Remember thee? 'tis thine owne already Boy, a hundred pounds shall not buy it from thee; giue me thy hand. I doe here create thee Lieftenant Innocentio.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: If you haue a company Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
If I haue: damne me if such another word doe not make me put thee out ath' place againe; if I haue a company, Sfut, let the Duke deny me one, I would twere come to that once, that employment should goe with the vndeseruer,
while men of seruice sit at home, and feede their anger with the blood of red lattices. Let the Duke denie me to day, Ile renounce him to morrow. Ile to the enimy point blanke, I'me a villaine else:

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And I by heauen I sweare.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well if that day come, it will proue a hot day with some body.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: But Captaine, did not you say that you would enter me at an Ordinary, that I might learne to conuerse?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: When thou wilt Lieftenant; No better time then now, for now th'art in good clothes, which is the most materiall point for thy entrance there.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: I but how should I behaue my selfe?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Marry Sir, when you come first in, you shall see a crew of Gallants of all sorts:

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Nay Captaine if I come first in I shall see no body.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Tush man, you must not doe so, if you haue good clothes and will be noted let am all come in afore you, and then as I said shall you see a lusty crew of Gallants, some Gentlemen, some none; but thats all one: he that beares himselfe like a Gentleman, is worthy to haue beene borne a Gentleman: some aged haue beards, and some haue none, some haue money, and some haue none, yet all must haue meate: Now will all these I say at your first entrance wonder at you, as at some strange Owle: Examine your person, and obserue your bearing for a time. Doe you then ath' tother side seeme to neglect their obseruance as fast, let your countenance be proofe against all eyes, not yeelding or confessing in it any inward defect. In a word be impudent enough, for thats your chiefe vertue of society.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Is that? faith and I neede not learne that, I haue that by nature I thanke God.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
So much the better, for nature is farre aboue Art, or iudgement. Now for your behauiour; let it be free and negligent, not clogg'd with ceremony or obseruance, giue
no man honour, but vpon equall termes; for looke how much thou giu'st any man aboue that, so much thou tak'st from thy selfe: he that will once giue the wall, shall quickly be thrust into the kennell: measure not thy carriage by any mans eye, thy speech by no mans eare, but be resolute and confident in doing and saying, and this is the grace of a right Gentleman as thou art.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Sfut, that I am I hope, I am sure my father has beene twise Warden on's company.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thats not a peare matter man, ther's no prescription for Gentility, but good clothes and impudence: for your place, take it as it fals, but so as you thinke no place to good for you; fall too with ceremony whatsoeuer the company be: and as neere as you can, when they are in their Mutton, be thou in thy Wood-cocke, it showes resolution. Talke any thing, thou car'st not what, so it be without offence, and as neere as thou canst without sence.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Let me alone for that Captaine I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: If you chance to tell a lye, you must binde it with some oath, as by this bread, for breads a binder you know.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: And yet take heede you sweare by no mans bread but your owne, for that may breede a quarrell: aboue all things you must carry no coales.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: By heauen not I, Ile freeze to death first.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well Sir, one point more I must remember you of. After dinner there will be play, and if you would be counted compleate, you must venture amongst them; for otherwise, theill take you for a Scholler or a Poet, and so fall into contempt of you: for there is no vertue can scape the accompt of basenesse if it get money, but gaming and law; yet must you not loose much money at once, for that argues little wit at all times.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: As gossaue me, and thats my fault; for if I be in once, I shall loose all I haue about me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Is true, Lieftenant? birlady Sir Ile be your moderator,
therefore let me see how much money haue you about you?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Not much, some twenty marke or twenty pound in gold.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Tis too much to loose by my faith, Lieftenant; giue me your purse Sir, hold yee, heers two brace of Angels, you shall venture that for fashion sake, Ile keepe the rest for you, till you haue done play.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: That will be all one, for when thats lost I shall neuer leaue till I get the rest from you: for I know thou wilt let me haue it if I aske it.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Not a penny by this gold.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Prethee doe not then, as gossaue me and you do:

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: And I doe, hang me; Come lets to the Duke.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Lucretia and Temperance, seuerall wayes.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: NAy Mistris, pray eene goe in againe, for I haue some inward newes for you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: What are those pray.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Tis no matter Mistris till you come in, but make much a time in the meane time, good fortune thrusts her selfe vpon you in the likenesse of a fine yong Gentleman, hold vp your apron and receiue him while you may, a Gods name.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: How say by that? y'are a very wise counsailer.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Well Mistris, when I was a Maide, and that's a good while agoe I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I thinke very well.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: You were but a little one then I wisse.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nor you neither I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Faith it's one of the furthest things I can remember.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: But what when you were a Maide?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Marry Mistris I tooke my time, I warrant you. And ther's Signior Leonoro now, the very flower of Venice, and one that loues you deerely I ensure you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: God forgiue him if he doe, for Ile be sworne I neuer deseru'd his loue, nor neuer will while I liue.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Why then, what say to Signior Collatine! ther's a dainty peece of Venzon for you, and a feruent louer indeed.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: He? I dare say, he knowes not what wood loues shafts are made of, his Signiory woud think it the deepest disparagement could be done to him, to say that euer he spent sigh for any Dame in Italy.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Well, you haue a whole browne dozen a suters at least, I am sure; take your choice amongst'em all, if you loue not all, yet you may loue three or foure on 'em to be doing withall.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: To be doing withall? loue three or foure?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Why not, so you loue 'em moderately. What must that strange made peece Theagines that you cry out vpon so often, haue all from other, and yet know not where he is?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: O my Theagine, not Theagines, thy loue hath turn'd me woman like thy selfe, shall thy sight neuer turne me man againe. Come lets to the Minster, God heare my prayers as I intend to stop mine eares against all my suters.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Well Mistris, yet peraduenture, they may make you open afore the Priest haue a penny for you,

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: HEer's a coyle to make wit and women friends: come hither wench, let me haue thee single; now sit thee downe, and heare good counsaile next thy heart, and God giue thee grace to lay it to thy heart.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Fie Cozen, will this wilde tongue of yours neuer receiue the bridle?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, thou shalt now see me stroke my beard, and speake sententiously: thou tellest me thy little father is in hand with a great rich marriage for thee, and would haue thee commit matrimony with old Gasparo, art thou willing with it?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I rather wish my selfe marryed to a thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Then I perceiue thou know'st him not; did he neuer wooe thee?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I protest, I neuer chang'd three words with him in my life; he hath once or twice woo'de my father for me, but neuer me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Why thats the reason thou lou'st him not, because thou tak'st in none of his valiant breath to enflame thee, nor vouchsaf'st his knowledge; Ile tell thee what he is, an old saplesse trunke, fit to make touch-wood of hollow, and bald like a blasted Oke, on whose top Rauens sit and croke the portents of funerals; one that noints his nose with clowced creame, and Pomatum. His breath smels like the butt end of a shoo-makers horne. A leprous scaly hide like an Elephant. The sonne of a Sow-gelder, that came to towne (as I haue heard thy father himselfe say) in a tottred russet cote, high shooes, and yet his hose torne aboue'em; A long pike-staffe in his necke (and a tord in his teeth) and a wallet on his right shoulder, and now the cullion hath with
Nouerint vniuersi eaten vp some hundred Gentlemen: he must needs rise a Gentleman as 'twere out of their Ashes, or disparage a Gentlewoman, to make himselfe a Gentleman, at least by the wiues side.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: The wurse my fortune to be entangled with such a winding bramble.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Entangl'd? Nay if I thought twould euer come to that, I'de hire some shag-ragge or other for halfe a chickeene to cut's throat, only to saue thy hands from doing it; for I know thou wouldst poison him within one moneth; loue thee he will neuer, and that must be thy happinesse: for if he doe, looke to be coop't vp like a prisoner, condemn'd to execution, scarce suffred to take the aire, so much as at a window, or waited on continually by an old beldame: not to keepe thee company, but to keepe thee from company: thy pocket searcht, thy cabinets ransackt for letters: euer in opposition, vnlesse (like the Moone) once a Moneth in coniunction; wealth thou maist haue indeede, but enioy it as in a dreame, for when thou wak'st thou shalt finde nothing in thy hand; (Enter Gasparo )and (to keepe my tale in goodnesse) see how all the ill that can be spoken of him is exprest in his presence.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: O ougly, and monstrous spectacle.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now tell me whether thou wouldst make choice of him or a yong gallant in prime of his choicenesse; one that for birth, person, and good parts, might meritoriously marry a Countesse; and one to whom his soule is not so deere as thy selfe. (Enter Aurelio )For all the world such another as he that comes here now: marke him well, see whether Gasparo and he be not a little different. Exit Aemilia .How now? Sownds Aurelio? stay beast, wilt thou make such a blest opportunity curse thee? Ile fetch her out to thee. Exit Lod.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: Wretch that I am, how shee lothes me? if I abide her, I shall consume in the lightnings of her anger. (Enter Lodouico with Aemilia.)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Here's a life indeede; what's he gone? passion of death, what a babe 'tis? I could finde in my heart to ierke him, but temper me friendship, no remedy now; now wit turne his defects to perfection. Why Cuze hee's quite out of sight. By my life I commend him; why this is done like thy selfe Aurelia, were shee the Queene of loue and woude runne from thee, flie thou from her; why now I loue thee, for I see th'art worthy of my loue, thou carriest a respect to thine owne worth, and wilt expresse it with spirit; I dare say, thou look'st to haue had him fall on his knees, and ador'd thee, or begge his life at thy hands: or else turn'd Queene Dido, and pierce his tender heart with sword full sharpe; no faith wench, the case is altered, loue made Hercules spin, but it made him rage after: there must goe time to the bridling of euery passion; I hope my friend will not loue a wench against her will, if shee woude haue met his kindnesse halfe way, so: if shee skit and recoile, he shootes her off warily, and away he goes: I marry Sir, this was a Gentlemanly part indeede. Farewell Cuze, be thou free in thy choice too, and take a better and thou canst a Gods name. Exiturus.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay deere Cuze, a word.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A word? what's the matter? I must needs after him, and clap him ath' backe, this spirit must be cherisht.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Alas what would you wish me to doe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why, nothing.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Would you counsaile me to marry him against my fathers will?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not for the world, leaue him, leaue him, leaue him: you see hee's resolu'd, hee'll take no harme an you, neuer feare to embrew your hands with his liuer I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Come you are such an other.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
This same riches with a husband, is the only thing in the world, I protest; good Gasparo, I am sorry I haue abused thee yfaith, for my Cozens sake; how prettily the wretch came crawling by with his crooked knees euen now:
I haue seene a yong Gentlewoman, liue as merry a life with an old man, as with the proudest yong vpstart on'em all: farewell Cuze, I am glad th'art so wise yfaith.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: If you goe, I die: fie on this affection, it rageth with suppression. Good Cuze, I am no longer able to continue it, I loue, Aurelio better then it is possible for him to loue me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Away, away, and could not this haue beene done at first, without all these superfluous disgracings? O this same vnhearty nicenesse of women, is good for nothing but to keepe their huswife hands still occupied in this warp of dissembling.
Well wench redeeme thy fault, and write a kinde letter to him presently, before this resolution of his take too deept roote in him.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay sweet Cuze, make me not so immodest, to write so sodainly, let me haue a little time to thinke vpon't.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thinke me on nothing till you write: thinke as you write, and then you shall be sure to write as you thinke. Women doe best when they least thinke on't.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: But rather then write I will meete him at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Meete him? dost thou thinke that I shall euer draw him againe to meete thee, that rush't from thee euen now with so iust a displeasure?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay good Cuze, vrge not my offence so bitterly, our next meeting shall pay the forfeit of all faults.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well th'art my pretty Cuze, and Ile doe my best to bring him to thee againe, if I cannot, I shall be sorry yfaith, thou wr't so iniuriously strange to him. But where shall this interview be now.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p:
There is the mischiefe, and we shall hardly auoide it, my father plies my haunts so closely: and vses meanes by our maide to entrap vs, so that this Tarrasse at our backe gate is the only place we may safely meete at: from whence I can stand and talke to you. But sweet Cuze you shall
sweare, to keepe this my kindnesse from Aurelio, and not intimate by any meanes that I am any thing acquainted with his comming.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Slife, do'st thinke I am an Asse? to what end should I tell him? hee and Ile come wandring that way to take the aire, or so, and Ile discouer thee.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: By meere chance as t'were.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: By chance, by chance, and you shall at no hand see him at first, when I bring him for all this kindnesse you beare him.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: By no meanes Cuze.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Very good: And if you endure any conference with him, let it be very little; and as neere as you can, turne to your former strangenesse in any case.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: If doe not Cuze, trust me not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Or if you thinke good, you may flirt away againe as soone as you see him, and neuer let your late fault be any warning t'ee.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I will doe all this, I warrant thee Cuze.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Will you so Cozen foole? canst thou be brought to that silly humour againe by any perswasions? by Gods Lord, and you be strange againe, more then needs must, for a temperat modesty, Ile break's necke downe from thee, but he shall doe as he did to thee.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Now, fie vpon you Cuze, what a foole doe you make me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well Dame, leaue your superfluous nicety in earnest, and within this houre I will bring him to this Tarrasse.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: But good Cuze if you chance to see my chamber window open, that is vpon the Tarrasse, doe not let him come in at it in any case.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Sblood how can he? can he come ouer the wall think'st?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: O Sir, you men haue not deuices with ladders of topes to scale such walles at your pleasure, and abuse vs poore wenches.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now a plague of your simplicity, would you discourage him with prompting him? well Dame, Ile prouide for you.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: As you loue me Cuze, no wordes of my kindnesse from me to him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Goe to, no more adoe. Exit Lodouico and Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: GOd yee God morrow Sir, truly I haue not heard a sweeter breath then your Page has.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I am glad you like him Mistris Temperance.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: And how dee Sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That I must know of you Lady, my welfare depends wholly vpon your good speede.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: How say Sir? and by my soule I was comming to you in the morning when your yong man came to me; I pray let him put on, vnlesse it be for your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He is yong, and can endure the cold well enough bare-headed.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: A pretty sweet child 'tis I promise you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But what good newes Mistris Temperance, will your Mistris be wonne to our kinde meeting?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Faith Ile tell you Sir, I tooke her in a good moode this morning, and broke with her againe about you, and shee was very pleasant as shee will be many times.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Very well, and is there any hope of speede?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: No by my troth Gentleman, none in the world, an obstacle yong thing it is, as euer I broke with all in my life: I haue broke with a hundred in my dayes, tho I say it, yet neuer met her comparison.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Are all my hopes come to this Mistris Temperance?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p:
Nay 'tis no matter Sir, this is the first time that euer
I spake to any in these matters, and It shall be the last God willing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And euen now shee had broke with a hundred and a hundred.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: But doe you loue her Sir indeede?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Do'st thou make a question of that?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Pardon me I pray Sir, I meane dee loue her as a Gentleman ought to doe, that is, to consummate matrimony with her as they say?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thats no matter to you Mistris Temperance, doe you procure our meeting, and let my fauour be at her hands as I can enforce it.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: You say like an honest Gentleman; a woman can haue no more: and faith Sir I wish you well, and euery day ter dinner my Mistris vses to go to her chaire or else lie down vpon her bedde, to take a nappe or so, to auoide idlenesse as many good huswifes do, you know, and then doe I sit by her and sew, or so: and when I see her fast a-sleepe, Lord doe I thinke to my selfe, (as you know we waiting women haue many light thoughts in our heads) Now if I were a man, and should beare my Mistris an ill will, what might I doe to her now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Indeede then you haue very good opportunity.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: The best that may be, for shee sleepes like a sucking Pigge, you may jogge her a hundred times, and shee'll stirre no more then one of your stones, here.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And could you put a friend in your place thinke you?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Nay birlady Sir, backe with that legge, for if any thing come on't but well, all the burthen will lye vpon me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why what can come of it? only that by this meanes I may solicite her loue my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: I but who knowes if the Deuill (God blesse vs) should be great wee', how you would vse her?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What do'st thou take me for a beast, to force her that I would make my wife?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Beast Sir; Nay ther's no beastlinesse in it neither, for a man will shew like a man in those cases: and besides, you may marre the bedde, which euery body will see that comes in; and that I would not for the best gowne I shall weare this twelue Moneth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well, to put thee out of that feare, it shall be worth such a gowne to thee.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: I thanke you for that Sir, but thats all one, and thus Sir, my old Master Honorio, at two a clocke will be at Tilting, and then will his sonne Signior Aurelio, and his man Angelo, be abroad; at which houre if you will be at the backe gate, and muffle your selfe handsomely, you may linger there till I call you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I marry Sir, so I may be there long enough.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Nay, but two a clocke, now, now is my houre Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Very well, and till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Boye to you hartily.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Boy to him indeede if he knew all. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I Haue prouided thee a ladder of ropes, therefore resolue to meete her, goe wash thy face, and prepare thy selfe to die, Ile goe make ready the ladder.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But when is the happy houre of our meeting?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry Sir, thats something vncertaine, for it depends wholly vpon her fathers absence, and when that will be God knowes: but I doubt not it will happen once within this twelue-Moneth.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sownds a twelue-Moneth.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Nay harke you, you are all vpon the spurre now, but how many louers haue seru'd seauen twelue-Moneths prenticeships, for the freedome of their Mistris fauours? notwithstanding to shorten your torments, your man Angelo
must be the meane, to draw the lap wing her father from his nest, by this deuice that I tell you. Enter Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I did euer dreame that once in my life good fortune would warme her cold hand in my naked bosome. And that once is now come, Ile lay hold vpon't, yfaith; I haue you my little squire, I haue you vpon mine Anueill, vpon which I will mallet you and worke you; coyning crownes, chickins, bracelets, and what not out of you; for procuring you the deere gullage of my sweete heart mistresse Francischina.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: I am glad it rests in my kinde seruant Angelo. Angelo, well met, it lies in thee now, make me no more thy master, but thy friend, and for euer happy in thy friendship.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: In what part of me does that lie Sir, that I may pull it out, for you presently?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: My friend Lodouico heere hath told me, what thou reuealedst to him to day, touching his vncle Lorenzo, and his louesute to Francischina.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Slight I told it him in secret sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And so did I tell it him Angelo, I am a Iew else.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It may well be sir, but what of that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This Angelo, he would haue thee procure my olde vnckles absence from home this afternoone, by making him meete or pretending his meeting with his mistresse, and thy sweete heart Francischina.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: Which if thou do'st Angelo, be sure of reward to thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What talke you of reward sir? to the louing and dutifull seruant, 'tis a greater encouragement to his seruice to heare his master say, God a mercy Angelo, spie out Angelo, Ile thinke of thy paines one day Angelo, then all your base rewards and preferments: yet not to hinder your hand sir, I will extend mine to his seruice presently, and get your old vncle (Signior Lorenzo) out of the waies long enough I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Tis honestly said, which when thou hast performed, enforce vs Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will not faile sir, I was resolu'd to make him away afore they spake to me, in procuring his accesse to Francischina, for what is his presence at her house, but his absence at his ownes? and thus shall I with one trewell daube two walles, (Enter Francisc. )see how fitly shee meetes me. I will stand close heere as if it were in my shop of good fortune, & in respect of all ornaments I can help her to, I will out of the fulnesse of my ioy, put her out of her studie and encounter her thus; Hold vp the bracelets. D'ee lacke gentlewoman, d'ee lacke: very fayre new gownes, kirtles, petticots, wrought smocks, bracelets, d'ee lacke gentlewoman, d'ee lacke?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What means my loue by these strange salutations?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Pre thee aske me no questions; hold take these bracelets, put vp this purse of gold quickly, and if thou wilt haue any of these things, I haue cried to thee, speake and tis performed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: From whose treasury comes all this, I pre thee?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Lorenzo, Lorenzo, a gentleman of much antiquitie, and one that for his loue hath burn'd hundreds of hearts to powder; yet now it fals out, that his tree of life is scorch't and blasted with the flames of thy beauty, readie to wither eternally, vnlesse it be speedily comforted with the sweete drops of thy nose.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Gods my life, is that old squire so amorous?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You wrong him to terme him old, he can draw his bow, ride his horse, vse his sword, and traile his pike vnder Loues colours, as well as euer he did.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I beleeue that easily.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well, go thy waies in and prepare to entertaine him now thy husband is from home, only with good words, and best kindnesses, making him put all into deeds till his treasury be deedlesse.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You speake as if I had nothing to respect but his entertainment, when you know how close and timely it must be put in execution, considering with what enuious eyes my neighbours suruey mee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Think'st thou, I consider not all this? he shall come in disguis'd, wench, and do thou deuise for our mirth, what ridiculous disguise he shall come in, and he shall assume it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What a magnifico of the Citie, and one of the Senate, thinkest thou he will not see into that inconuenience?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No more then no Senator, for in this case, my assurance is that Cupid will take the scarfe from his owne eyes, and hoodwinke the old buzzard, while two other true turtles enioy their happinesse: get thee in I beseech thee loue, tell thy gold, and say thy prayers. (Enter Lorenzo. )Now for a farre fetch't deuice to fetch ouer my loue-squire. Exit

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I see him within eare-shot; well may beauty inflame others, riches may tempt others; but for mee, mine eares and mine eyes, are proofe against all the Syrens, and Venusses, in all the seas of the world; beauty is a whore, riches a baud, and Ile trust none an you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What ailes poore Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay mistresse Franke, if you proue disloyall once, farewell all constancy in women.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How now man? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O Sir are you so neare? I shall trust your experience in women the better while I liue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I pre thee why so?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Say true Sir, did you neuer sollicite your loue-sute to fayre mistresse Francischina?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Neuer I protest Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Vpon my life 'tis a strange thing; I would haue sworne all Italy, could not so sodainly haue fastned a fauour vpon her, I look't for a siege of Troy at least, to surprize the turrets of her continence; but to yeeld at the first sight of her assaylants colours, and before any Cannon was mounted afore her, 'tis one of the loosest parts of a modest woman that euer I heard of.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How saist thou? did not I tell thee as much? beware of an old colt while you liue, he can tell when to strike I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Women and fethers? now fie on that affinity.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Alas Angelo, a feeble generation, soone ouercome God knowes, the honester minde, the sooner ouercome.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Gods my life, what light huswife would yeeld at first to a stranger, and yet does this whirligig stand vpon termes of honour forsooth? tenders her reputation as the Apple of her eye; she has a ielous and a cutting husband, enuious neighbours, and will die many deathes rather then by any friends open accesse to her, be whip't naked with the tongues of scandall and slander; and a whole sanctuary of such ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O she does worthily in that Angelo, and like a woman of honour, thou hast painted her perfection in her faults thou find'st, and tickil'st me with her appetite.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And to auoid all sight of your entrance, you must needs come in some disguise she sayes; so much she tenders your high credit in the Citie, and her owne reputation, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How, come in some disguise?

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: A toy, a very toy which runnes in her head with such curious feete Sir, because if there be any resemblances of your person seene to enter her house, your whole substantiall selfe will be called in question; any other man she saies, might better aduenture with the least thing chang'd about 'em then you with all; as if you were the onely noted mutton-monger in all the Citie.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well Angelo, heauen forgiue vs the sinnes of our youth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: That's true Sir, but for a paltry disguise, being a magnifico, she shall goe snicke vp.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Soft good Angelo, soft, let's think on't a little: what disguise would serue the turne saies shee?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Faith, I know not what disguise shee would haue for you: shee would haue you come like a Calfe with a white face, I thinke, shee talkes of Tinkers,
pedlers, porters, chimney-sweepers, fooles and Physitians, such as haue free egresse and regresse into mens houses without suspicion.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Out vpon 'em, would she haue me vndergoe the shame and hazard of one of those abiects?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Yfaith I told her so, a squire of that worship, one of the Senate, a graue Iusticer, a man of wealth, a magnifico?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And yet by my troth, for the safegard of her honour, I would doe much; me thinks a Friers weede were nothing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Out vppon't, that disguise is worne thread bare vpon euery stage, and so much villany committed vnder that habit; that 'tis growne as supicious as the vilest. If you will hearken to any, take such a transformance, as you may be sure will keepe you from discouery: for though it be the stale refuge of miserable Poets, by change of a hat or a cloake, to alter the whole state of a Comedie, so as the father must not know his owne child forsooth, nor the wife her husband, yet you must not thinke they doe it earnest to carry it away so: for say you were stuffed into a motley coate, crowded in the case of a base Violl, or buttond vp in a cloak-bag, euen to your chinne, yet if I see your face, I am able to say this is signior Lorenzo, and therefore vnlesse your disguise be such that your face may beare as great a part in it as the rest, the rest is nothing.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Good reason, in faith Angelo; and what, shall I then smurch my face like a chimney sweeper, & weare the rest of his smokinesse?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ile tell you sir, if you be so mad to condescend to the humour of a foolish woman, by consideration that Ioue for his loue tooke on him the shape of a Bull, which is farre worse then a chimney sweeper, I can fit you rarely.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: As how I pre thee?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: There is one little snaile you know, an old chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
What, hee that sings, Maids in your smocks, hold
open your locks, fluds.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: The very same sir, whose person (I borrowing his words) you will so liuely resemble, that himselfe in person cannot detect you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But is that a fit resemblance to please a louer Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: For that sir, she is prouided: for you shall no sooner enter but off goes your rustie skabberd, sweete water is readie to scoure your filthy face, milk, & a bath of fernebraks for your fustie bodie, a chamber perfum'd, a wrought shirt, night cap, and her husbands gowne, a banquet of Oysters pyes, Potatoes, Skirret rootes, Eringes, and diuers other whetstones of venery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O let me hugge thee Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A bed as soft as her hayre, sheets as delicate as her skinne, and as sweete as her breath, pillowes imitating her breasts, and her breasts to boote, Hypocras in her cups, and Nectar in her lips, Ah, the gods haue bene beasts for lesse felicitie.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No more good Angelo, no more, how shall I requite the happinesse thou wilt bring me too? haste any mind of marriage?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Not much sir, but an extraordinary wife might tempt me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By my troth and she were not promist, thou shouldest haue my daughter: but come lets to our disguise, in which I long to be singing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ile folow you presently. Exit. Signior Lodouico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why sir, I am prouiding meanes to leade your old vncle out ath' way, as you will'd me, by drawing him into the way of Quintilianoes wife, my sweet heart, and so make roome for him by Quintilianoes roome: you that lead him any way, must needes seeke him out and employ him to some tauerne.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He will be with me presently Angelo, and here's a freshman come from Padua, whom I will powder with his acquaintance, and so make him an excellent morsell to rellish his carouses.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Goe to Sir, by this light you'll be complain'd on, there cannot be a foole within twenty mile of your head, but you engrosse him for your owne mirth: Noble-mens tables cannot be seru'd for you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Stut, Ile complaine of them man, they hunt me out and hang vpon me, so that I cannot be ridde on'em, but they shall get some body else to laugh at, or Ile turne'em ouer to our Poets, and make all the world laugh at'em.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well Sir, here comes your man, make him sure from his wife, and I'le make the tother sure with her. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Innocentio, Fannio, Taylor, Taylors sonne, he Reades a bill.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: SEe Signior Gionanelle, here comes the famous Captaine you would so faine bee acquainted withall; be acquainted with him at your perill: Ile defend you from his swaggering humor, but take heede of his cheating.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, I haue not beene matriculated at the Vniuersity, to be meretriculated by him: salted there to be colted here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Very well Sir, lets heare him.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: I haue examin'd the particulars of your bill Master Taylor, and I finde them true Orthographie, thy payment shall be correspondent: marry I will set no day, because I am loth to breake.

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.p:
Alas Sir, pray let this be the day: consider my charge. I haue many children, and this my poore child here whom I haue brought vp at schoole, must loose all I haue bestowed on him hitherto, if I pay not his Master presently
the quartridge I owe him.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Foole do'st thou delight to heare thy sonne begge in Latin, pose him Lieftenant.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: How make you this in Latin boy? My father is an honest Taylor.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That will hardly be done in true Latin Sir.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: No? why so Sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Because it is false English sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: An excellent Boy.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Why is it false English?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Marry sir, as bona Mulier is said to be false Latin, because though bona be good, Mulier is naught; so to say my father is an honest Taylor, is false English; for though my father be honest, yet the Taylor is a theefe.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Beleeue it a rare shred, not of home-spunne cloth vpon my life: Taylor, goe, send the schoole-master to me at night and Ile pay him.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Thanke you good Captaine, and if you doe not pay him, at night my wife will come to you her selfe, that's certaine, and you know what a tongue shee has.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Like the sting of a Scorpion, shee nailes mine eares to the pillory with it, in the shame and torment shee does me. Goe I will voide this Bill and auoide her.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I thanke you sir. Exit cum filio.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Lieftenant, is not this a braue gullery? The slaue has a pretty wife, and shee will neuer haue me pay him, because shee may euer come to my chamber, as shee sayes, to raile at me, and then shee goes home and tels her husband shee has tickled me yfaith.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: By my life, a rare jest.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou maist see this Boy is no shred of a Taylor, is he not right of my looke and spirit?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Right as a line, yfaith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: And will agree in the halter.— Saue you Captaine Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
And do'st thou liue my noble Lodouico? Boy, take
my cloake, when shals haue a rouse, ha? my Lieftenant and I were drunke last night, with drinking health on our knees to thee.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Why, would not your legs beare you Sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: How many miles to midsommer? S'blood, whose foole are you? are not you the tassell of a Gander?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: No indeede not I Sir: I am your poore friend Sir glad to see you in health.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Health? S'fut, how meane you that? dee thinke I came lately out ath' powdering Tubbe?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Gossaue mee Sir 'twas the furthest part of my thought.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why y'are not angry, are you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No, nor you shall not be.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'blood, I hope I may and I will.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Be and you dare Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Dare?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I, dare.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Plague on thee, th'art the mad'st Lodouico in the world, s'fut doe thou stabbe me, and th'ast a minde too't, or bid me stabbe my selfe, is this thy friend? do'st thou loue Lodouico?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: With my heart I protest Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'heart, a lyes in's throate that does not; and whence com'st thou wagge, ha?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Euen new arriued from Padua Sir to see fashions.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Giue me thy hand, th'art welcome; and for thy fashions, thou shalt first drinke and wench it: to which end we will carouse a little, some sixe or seauen miles hence, and euery man carry his wench.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: But where shall we haue them Captaine?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Haue'em Lieftenant? if we haue'em not, my Valentine shall be one, and shee shall take a neighbour or two with her to see their nurst childes or so; wee'll want for no wenches I warrant thee, (Enter Cuthbert Barber.)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: But who comes here?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O tis my Barber.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: S'blood how thy trades men haunt thee.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Alas they that liue by men, must haunt'em,

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: God saue you Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: How now Cutberd, what newes out of Barbary?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sir, I would borrow a word with you in priuate.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Be briefe then Cutbeard, thou look'st leane me thinks, I thinke th'art newly marryed.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I am indeede Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I thought so, keepe on thy hat man, twill be the lesse perceiu'd, what, is not my Taylor and you friends yet? I will haue you friends thats certaine, Ile maintaine you both else.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: I know no enmity betwixt vs Sir, you know Captaine I come about another matter.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why but Cutbeard, are not you neighbours? your trades Cosen german, the Taylor and the Barber? does not the Taylor sow? doest not thou Barber reape? and doe they not both band themselues against the common enemy of mankinde, the louse? are you not both honest men alike? is not he an arrant knaue? you next dore to a knaue, because next dore to him?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Alas Sir, all this is to no purpose, there are certaine odde crownes betwixt vs you know.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: True Cutbeard, wilt thou lend me as many moe to make'em euen Boy?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Faith Sir, they haue hung long enough a conscience.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Cut'em downe then Cutbeard, it belongs to thy profession if they hang too long.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Well Sir if this be all, Ile come by'em as I can, and you had any honesty.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: S'blood honesty you knaue? doe you taxe any Gentleman in this company for his honesty?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p:
Blame me not sir, I am vndone by him, and yet
I am still of as good credit in my Parish as he too.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'blood Rascall, as good credit as I?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay pre thee Captaine forbeare.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Good Captaine be gone.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Let me alone; Ile not strike him by this hand, why hearke yee Rogue: put your credit in ballance with mine? do'st thou keepe this company? here's Signior Lodouico, one of the Clarissimi, a man of worship: here's a Gentleman of Padua, a man of rare parts, an excellent scholler, a fine Ciceronian.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: And here's my Lieftenant, I hope thou know'st the Worshipfull man his father with the blew beard, and all these are my companions; and dare you a barbarous slaue, a squirting companion, compare with me? but here's the point; now behold and see: Signior Giouenelle, lend me foure or fiue pounds, let it be fiue pounds, if you haue so much about you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Here's my purse sir, I thinke there be iust so much in't.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Very good, now Cutbeard, are you a slanderous cut-throat or no? will thy credit doe this now? without scrip or scrowle. But thou wilt thinke this is done for a colour now; doe you not lend it me simply?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: What a question's that?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: For how long?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: At your pleasure Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why so, here you poling Rascall, here's two crownes out of this money: now I hope wilt beleeue 'tis mine, now the property is altered.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why you might a done this before then.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: No Cutbeard, I haue beene burnd ith' hand for that, Ile pay n'ere a knaue an yee all money, but in the presence of such honest Gentleman that can witnesse it; of my conscience I haue paid it thee halfe a dozen times; goe to sir be gone.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Fare yee well sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thanke you Signior Giouenelle; though y'are sure of this money againe at my hands, yet take heede how this same Lodouico get it from you, he's a great sharker; but th'ast no more money about thee hast thou?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Not a doit, by this candle.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: All the better, for hee'd cheat thee on't, if thou had'st euer so much, therefore when thou com'st to Padua, ply thy booke and take good courses, and 'tis not this againe shall serue thy turne at my handes, I sweare to thee.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Thanke you good Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Signior Lodouico, adiew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not so sir, we will not part yet, a carouse or two me thinks is very necessary betwixt vs.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: With all my heart Boy, into the Emperours head here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Content.

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Say Sir, haue you plaid the man and hous'd the Captaine?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I haue hous'd and lodg'd him in the Emperours head Tauerne, and there I haue left him glorified with his two guls, so that presume of what thou wilt at his house, for he is out of the way by this time both waies.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
T'is very well handled sir, and presume you & your friend my master Aurelio of what may satisfie you at your
vncles, for he is now going out of the way, and out of himselfe also: I haue so besmeard him with a chimney sweepers resemblance, as neuer was poore Snaile, whose counterfaite he triumphes in, neuer thinking I haue daubd his face sufficient, but is at his glasse as curiously busied to beautifie his face (for as of Moo'rs so of chimney sweepers) the blackest is most beautifull as any Lady to paint her lips.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Thou art a notable villaine.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am the fitter for your imployment Sir: stand close I beseech you, & when I bring him into the streets, encounter and bayte him in stead of Snayle, but in any case let none else know it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: If you should tell it to one, so you charge him to say nothing, 'twere nothing, and so if one by one to it play holy water frog with twentie, you know any secret is kept sufficiently; and in this, we shall haue the better sport at a Beare baiting, fare ye well Sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: SIgnior Lodouico good euen to you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: The like to Signior Honorio, and harke you Sir, I must be bound with my vncle Lorenzo, and tell you a pleasant secrete of him, so in no sort you will vtter it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: In no sort as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why Sir hee is to walke the streets presently in the likenesse of Snayle the chimney sweeper, and with his crie.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What is hee Sir? to what end I beseech you Sir wil hee disfigure himselfe so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yfaith Sir I take it for some matter of pollicy, that concernes towne gouernment.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Towne-bull gouernment, do you not meane so Sir?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: O no Sir, but for the generall businesse of the Citie I take it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Well sir well we will not examine it too farre, but gesse at it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So sir when he comes forth do you take one corner to encounter him as I will doe another, and taking him for Snayle, imagine hee went about stealing of Citie venison, (though he do not,) and make what sport you thinke good with him, alwaies prouided it be cleanly, and that he may still thinke he goes inuisible.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I warraut yee Signior Lodouico, and thanke you hartily for this good cause of our honest recreation.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Scarce honest neither sir, but much good do it you, as it is,

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: O that my sonne, your friend Aurelio, were heere to helpe to candy this ieast a little.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Alas sir, his sicke stomacke can abide no sweete meates, hee's all for aye me, wee'll make the Ieast rellish well enough I warrant you: Lorenzo my vncle an old Senator, one that has read Marcus Aurelius, Gesta Romanorum, the Mirror of Magistrates, &c. to be led by the nose like a blind Beare that has read nothing. Let my man reade how hee deserues to be bayted.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty wonder yfaith Signior Lodouico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Slife, 'twere a good deed, to get boyes to pinne cards at his backe, hang squibs at his tayle, ring him through the towne with basons, besnowball him with rotten egges, and make him asham'de of the Commission before hee scale it.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: What saies Signior Lodouico, I beseech you sir? me thinkes his pleasant disposition should intend some waggerie.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: I will tell you Signior Gasparo, but in any case you must say nothing.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: In no case will I say any thing sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Then this is the case: Signior Lorenzo (your probable father in law) in the case of Snayle the chimney sweeper, will straight tread the streets for his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gasp
sp.p: For his pleasure?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: For his pleasure sir, say it be so, wonder not, but ieast at it, consider what pleasure the world sayes he is most giuen to, and helpe baite him hereafter, but in any case cleanly, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: O monstrous, I conceiue you, my father in law, will his daughter haue his tricks thinke you?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Faith for that you must euen take fortune de la pace, kisse the Paxe, and be patient like your other neighbours. So, here stand I, chose you another place.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: O me, what if a man should call him to sweepe a chimney in earnest, what would he doe? Ile put him too't a my credit, and here will I stand. (Enter Lorenzo with his glasse in his hand, and Angelo with a pot of painting.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How now sir, are you well yet thinke you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A little more here good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Very well sir, you shall haue enough.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It will be the most perfect disguise that euer was imitated.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ile warrant you that yfaith sir; ya're fitted beyonde the forehead for a right counterfaite; It is well now sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Yet a little more heere Angelo, and then master Painter let Michael Angelo himselfe amend thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: For a perfect naturall face, I care not if all the world explaine it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: So now take this glasse, and giue me my furniture, and haue at your smoaky chimney.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Haue at your smoakie chimney Mistresse Franke: heere sir take vp your occupation, and downe with Snayle for a chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Away, see if the coast be cleare.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Take good view, looke about to the doores and windowes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Not a dogge at a doore, not a cat at a window.
Appeare in your likenesse, and not with your quality.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Chimney sweepe; worke for chimney sweepe, wilt do sirha?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Admirably.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Does my sute become me?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Become you sir? would to heauen mistresse Franke could bring you to the wearing of it alwaies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Ile forth yfaith then; Maids in your smocks, set open your locks,
Downe, downe, downe:
Let Chimney sweeper in:
And he will sweepe your chimneys cleane,
Hey derry, derry, downe.
How do'st like my crie, ha?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Out of all crie, I forbid Snayle himselfe to creepe beyond you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: As God helpe, I begin to be proud on't: Chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Gods pitty, who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My nephew Lodowicke; Gods me, Ile start backe againe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay ther's no starting now, hee'll see you go into your house then; fall into your note; stand to Snayles person and I warrant you. (Enter Lodouico.) Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now Snayle, how do'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thanke your good worship.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Me thinkes thy song is more hearty then 'twas wont to be, and thou look'st much better.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thanke God and good friends sir; and a merry heart that prolongs life. Chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay good Snayle, lets talke a little, you know Rose mine vncle Lorensoes maide Snayle!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: That I do well sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She complaines of you Snayle, and sayes, y'are the bawdiest old knaue in venery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Alas sir, she wrongs me: I am not fedde thereafter, let her looke for that commendation in her richer customers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who are they Snayle? I hope you doe not meane mine vncle her Master; hee's mine vncle and I loue him well, and I know the old lickspiggot will be nibling a little when he can come too't: but I must needs say he will do no hurt, hee's as gentle as an Adder that has his teeth taken out.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Y'are a merry Gentleman sir; and I haue hastie labour in hand, I must craue pardon. (Enter Honorio. )Chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: What old Snayle? how do'st thou and thy chimneyes?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry sir I was asking him questions about one of them.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: What Signior Lodouico? what one is that I pray?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Mine vncle Lorenzos maide Rose sir, and hee will needs perswade me, her old master keepes her for his owne saddle.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Her old master? I dare sweare they wrong him that say so; his very age would make him asham'd to be ouertaken with those goatish licences.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: True sir, and his great authority in the Citie, that should whippe such vnseasonable letchers about the wals of it.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Why, y'are ith' right sir, and now you talke of your vncle, I heard say Captaine Quintiliano cheated him yesterday of fiue pounds, as hee did a yong Gentleman of Padua this morning of as much more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Faith sir he drew such a kinde of tooth from him indeede.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Is it possible he should be so wrought vpon by him? Now certaine I haue euer held him a most wise Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
An arrant Rooke by this light; a capable cheating
stocke; a man may carry him vp and downe by the eares like a pipkin.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: But do you thinke he will let the Captaine passe so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why alas, what should he doe to him sir? the pasture is so bare with him, that a goose cannot graze vpon't.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Marry sir then would I watch him a time when he were abroad, and take out my penniworthes of his wife, if hee drew a tooth from me, I would draw another from her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well, God be with your worships: chimney sweeper, I thought I should neuer haue bene ridde of them, (Enter Gasparo )Chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: What old Snayle, do'st thou crie chimney sweepe still? why they say thou art turnd mightie rich of late.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I would they said true sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Yes by the masse, by the same token, that those riches make thy old name for venery encrease vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Foolish tales sir, foolish tales.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Yes by the masse, Snayle, but they be told for such certaine tales, that if thou hast a daughter to marrie with tenne thousand crownes, I would see her pithole, afore I would deale with her, for feare she should trot through her fathers trumperies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Alas sir your worship knowes, I haue neither daughter nor riches, Idle talke sir, Idle talke: chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Nay stay Snayle, and come into my house, thou shalt earne some money of mee, I haue a chimney to sweepe for thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I thanke your worship, I will waite vpon you next morning early sir: but now I haue promi'st to sweepe another mans chimney in truth.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: But good Snayle take mine in the way.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What does he crie chimney sweepe, and refuse to sweepe 'em?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
No master, alas you know I liue by it, and now I
crie as I go to worke that I haue promi'st, that I may get more against other times: what would ye haue me do thee?

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Alas poore Snayle; farewell good Snayle, farewell.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Lord keepe your good worship.— And a very vengeance, I beseech the blacke father of vengeance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Poore vncle, he begins to be melancholy, has lost his song among's

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Was neuer such man touch't with such ouersight?

sp.speaker: Hon:
sp.p: Beare with age, Signior Gasparo, beare with age, and let vs all tender his credite as we haue vow'd, and be silent; he little thought to haue beene thus betrayed as he is; and where secrecy is assur'd, it beares with many bad actions in the very best I can tell you, and so good Signior Lodouico adew, and I heartily thanke you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Adue good Signior Honorio.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Adue to you likewise sir. Exeunt Gasparo & Honorio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Likewise to you sir. Alas poore vncle, I haue monstrously abused him; and yet maruellous worthie, for he disparageth the whole bloud of vs; and I wish all such old sheepebiters might alwaies dippe their fingers in such sauce to their mutton; but thus will he presently bee safe; for by this hee is neere his sweete hearts house, where he is like to be entertain'd with worse cheere then we made him. Quintilliano is now carousing in the Emperours head, while his owne head buddes hornes to carouse in; and in the meane time will my amorous friend and I, make both their absences shooing hornes to draw on the presence of Aemilia. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: WHat sayes your worship now? Do you not walke inuisible, all your ancient acquaintance, your owne nephew to talke with you and neuer discouer you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But Angelo, a villanous feare shooke me the whiles I sweare, for still I was afraid my tongue would haue likt away the soote of my face, and bewrayed me; but Snayle, hitherto thy rustie shell has protected me: perseuer till I haue yonder house a my head, hold in thy hornes, till they looke out of Quintillianoes forehead: for an old man to make a yong man cuckold, is one of Hercules labours.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: That was the cleansing of other mens stables.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To make youth rampant in age, and age passant in youth, to take a man downe at his owne weapon; to call backe time in one, and thrust him headlong vpon another.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now your worship is Oracle to your owne miracles; how you shine in this smoaky cloud? which you make the golden net to embrace Venus, y'aue past the pikes yfaith and all the Iayles of the loue-god swarme in yonder house, to salute your recouery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Wel Angelo, I tell thee, now we are past the danger, I would not for 40 crowns but haue heard, what I haue heard.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: True sir, now you know what the world thinks on you, 'tis not possible for a great man, that shines alwaies in his greatnesse, to know himselfe; but O twice yong Leander, see where your Hero stands with torch of her beauty to direct you to her tower, aduance your sweet note, & vpon her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Chimney sweepe, worke for chimney sweepe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come in chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why now sir thine Angelo is your good Angell; enter and prosper, and when you are in the mid'st of your happinesse, thinke of him that prefer'd you. Exit Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Fran.
