sp.p: Angelo, giue him not too much time with me, for feare of the worst, but goe presently to the backe gate, and vse my husbands knocke, then will I presently thrust him into my cole-house: and there shall the old flesh-monger fast for his iniquity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well said mine owne Franke yfaith, we shall trim him betwixt vs, I for the most slouenly case in the towne; shee, for the most sluttish place in the house: Neuer was old horse-man so notoriously ridden; well, I will presently knocke him into the cole-house, and then haste to Lodouico, to know when he shall be releast. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lodouico with a ladder of ropes, Aurelio, (Aemilia aboue.)

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: HEre's thy ladder, and ther's thy gallowes, thy Mistris is thy hangman, and must take thee downe: This is the Tarrasse where thy sweet heart tarries; what wouldst thou call it in Rime?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Celestiall spheare, wherein more beauty shines.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Roome for a passion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then on Dardanian Ida, where the pride
Of heauens selected beauties striu'd for prize.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay you shall know, we haue watred our houses in Helicon. I cannot abide this talking and vndoing Poetry, leaue your mellifluous numbers: yonder's a sight will steale all reason from your rime I can tell you; downe of your knees you slaue, adore. Now lets heare you inuocate, O the saple hammes of a louer, goe to, doe not, stand vp close, for she must not see you yet, though she know you are here.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Cozen Lodowicke?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who cals Lodowicke?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: What tempest hath cast you on this sollitary shore? Is the party come?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
The party? now a plague of your modesty, are
your lips too nice to name Aurelio?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Well, is he come then?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He, which he? s'fut name your man with a mischiefe to you, I vnderstand you not.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Was there euer such a wild-braine? Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aurelio? Lord how loth you are to let any sound of him come out an you, you hold him so deare within, Ile present her with a sight, will startle her nicety a little better; hold you, fasten the end of this ladder I pray.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Now Iesus blesse vs, why cosen, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Goe to you spirit of a feather, be not so soft hearted, leaue your nicety, or by this hemp Ile so hamper thy affections in the halter of thy louers absence, making it vp in a gordian knot of forgetfulnesse, that no Alexander of thy allurements, with all the swordes of thy sweet words, shall euer cut in peeces.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Lord, how you roule in your rope-ripe termes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Goe to, tell me, will you fasten the ladder or no?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I know not what I should say t'ee: I will fasten it, so only your selfe will come vp.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Only my selfe will come vp then.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay sweet Cuze, sweare it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If I should sweare thou wouldst curse me: take my word in a halters name, and make the ladder as fast to the Tarrasse, as thou would'st be to Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay see if he doe not make me giue ouer againe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Was there euer such a blew kitling? fasten it now, or by heauen thou do'st loose me for euer.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Well sir, remember your word; I will fasten it, but yfaith Cuze, is not the Gentleman, and his parting choller parted yet?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yfaith with much adoe:

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay, nay, choose him; I shall liue, if they be not: and if I liue till his choller kill me, I shall liue till he leaue louing me, and that will be a good while first.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Lord, Lord, who has enform'd you of such amorous
feruency in him: are you so confident in his kindnesse?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, tis but a carelesse confidency neither, which alwaies last longer then that which is timorous: well Cuze, here I haue fastned it for your pleasure; but alas, the feare of my fathers comming does so distract me that I scarce know what I doe or say.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Your father? do'st thinke we would venture all this preparation, and not make him safe?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: But are you sure he is safe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Am I sure this is Aurelio? looke vpon him wench, is it not thy loue? thy life? come sir, mount.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: O cosen Lodwicke, doe you thus cosen and betray me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Cuze, Cuze, thou hast acted thy dissembling part long enough, in the most modest iudgement, and passing naturally: giue ouer with thy credit then, vnmaske thy loue, let her appeere in her natiue simplicity, striue to conceale her no longer from thy loue, for I must needs tell thee he knowes all.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: What does he know?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why all that thou told'st me, that thou lou'st him more then he can loue thee, that thou hast set vp thy resolution, in despight of friends or foes, weales or woes, to let him possesse thee wholly, and that thou didst wooe me to bring him hither to thee: All this he knowes; that it was thy deuice to prepare this ladder, and in a word, all the speech that past betwixt thee and me he knowes, I told him euery word truly and faithfully Gods my Iudge.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Now was there euer such an immodest creature?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Via, with all vaine modesty, leaue this colouring, and strip thy loue starke naked, this time is too precious to spend vainly; mount I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Modell of heauenly beauty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Sownds, wilt thou melt into rime a the tother side? shall we haue lines? change thy stile for a ladder, this
will bring thee to Parnassus, vp I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Vnworthy I t'approach the furthest step to that felicity that shines in her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O spurblinde affection, I haue seene a fellow, to a worse end ascend a ladder with a better will, and yet this is in the way of marriage, and they say, marriage and hanging haue both one constellation. To approue the which old saying, see if a new ladder make 'em not agree.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Peace, some bodie comes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: That you heard, was but a mouse, so boy I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O sacred goddesse, what soe're thou art
That in meere pitty to preserue a soule
From vndeseru'd destruction, hast vouchsaf't
To take Aemiliaes shape.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What a poeticall sheepe is this? S'life, will you stand riming there vpon a stage, to be an eye-marke to all that passe? is there not a chamber by? withdraw I say for shame, haue you no shame in you? heere will come some bodie presently I lay my life on't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Deare mistresse, to auoid that likely danger,
Vouchsafe me onely priuate conference,
And 'tis the fulnes of my present hopes. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
Aurelio, Occasion is bald, take her by the forelock; so, so. In Hymens name get you together, heere will I stand Sentinell. This is the backe gate to Honorios house, which shall be Aurelios, if God giue him grace to weepe for his fathers death in time. And in this garden, if I could see the chaste Lucresse, or the affable mistresse Temperance, I might (thus wrapt in my cloake) steale a little courtship through the chinke of a pale. But indeed I thinke it safer to sit closer, and so to cloud the summe of my visnomy, that no eye discerne it. (He sits downe, and muffles himselfe in his cloake. )So be it, thats my resolution. Now to my contemplation, this is no Pandarisme, is it?
No, for there is neither money nor credit propos'd or expected, and besides there is no vnlawfull act intended, no not this same lasciua actio animi: I thinke for his part, much lesse hers: go to, let me do my kinswoman, and her sex right, sit at rest with me then reputation, and conscience, fall asleepe with the world, but this same idle attendance is the spite of it, Idlenesse is accounted with other men a sinne, to me 'tis a penance, I was begot in a stirring season, for now hath my soule a thousand fancies in an instant, as what wench dreams on when she lies on her backe, when one hen layes an egge and another sits it, whether that hen shall mother that chicken? If my bull leape your cow, is not the calfe yours? yes no doubt, for Aedificium cedit solo saies the Lawyer: and then to close all comes in a sentence, Non omnia possumus omnes: for some are borne to riches, others to verses, some to be bachelers, others to be cuckolds, some to get crownes, and others to spend'm, some to get children, and others to keepe'em: and all this is but idlenesse, would to God I had some scuruy poeme about me to laugh at, (Enter Temperance. )but marke, yonders a motion to be seene.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: Yonder he sits yfaith, well done true loue, good Signior Leonoro, he keepes promise the best, he does not see me yet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Tis the stai'd Madam Temperance, a pretty pinnace she has bene in her daies, and in her nights too, for her burthen, and reasonable good vnder sayle, and see she hath discouered a sayle, see, see, she hales him in, ha? tis this way to the rewards, slight 'tis this way: I hope the baud knowes not me, and yet I know not, she may be a witch, for a whore she was before I knew her, a baud I haue knowne her any time this dozen years, the next step to honour then is a witch, because of Nature, for where the whore ends, the baud begins, and the corruption of a baud, is the generation of a witch. And Pythagoras holds opinion, that a witch turnes to a wild Cat, as an old Ostler turnes to an ambling nagge. Enter Leonoro muffled in his cloake with Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This is the backe gate, where Temperance should meete me at this howre.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.p: I wonder she fayles, for I see her not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why sits that fellow there troe? come let's houer here abouts 'twill not be long er'e we encounter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So, now this riddle is expounded, this baud tooke me for this aduenturer whom (twentie to one) she attended, to waft him into Lucretias chamber, what a beast was I, not to apprehend this aduantage, thus muffled as I am, she could not haue perceiued mee till I had been in, And I might safely haue staid a while without endangering my louers: (Enter Temperance stealing along the stage. )S'light she takes me still for her first man.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Come, come, gingerly for Gods sake, gingerly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: See Lyonell, yet she is not come, and the priuy attendant is gone.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: I wonder what it was.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I feare me some other clyent of hers, whom she preferres before me, come, we must not linger here too long together, wee'll enter on this backside, to the Emperours head, where we will stay a little, and then make the last triall of this bauds honesty. (Enter Quintiliano, Giouenelli, and Fannio in their doublet and hose.)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come Ancient, lets leaue our company a little, and ayre our selues in this backside.— Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: A friend.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: The word.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: God saue you Captaine Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Shote him Ancient, a spie, the word's the Emperours head, and thither you shall go sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pardon me good Captaine.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Come, be not retrograde to our desires.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I attend a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Th'ast attended him already, I am witnesse too't, deni't and he dare, whatsoe're he bee, and he shall attend thee another while, and he will: Th'art as good a man as he, and he be the Duke himselfe, for a Clarissimo; entertaine him Ancient, bid the Clarissimo, welcome, Ile call a drawer, and wee'll haue some wine in this Arbor. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: Y'are very welcome Signior Clarissimo, desire you more acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My name is Leonoro sir, & indeed I scarce know you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: No sir, and you know me, you must know as much as I know, for Scientia and Scientificus is all one; but that's all one, in truth sir, you shall not spend a penny here, I had money, I thanke God euen now, and peraduenture shall haue againe e're we part, I haue sent to a friend of mine.

div.stage: (Enter Quintilliano and a drawer with a cup of wine & a towell.)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Here honourable Clarissimo, I drinke to thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thanke you good Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'fut, winesucker, what haue you fild vs heere, baldredash? taste Leonoro.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Me thinks 'tis sacke.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Let vs taste sir, 'tis claret, but it has beene fetch't againe with Aqua vitae.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'light me thinks t'as taken salt water, who drew this wine you rogue?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: My fellow Sam drew it sir, the wine's a good neat wine, but you loue a pleasanter grape, I'le fit your pallate sir. (He stands close.)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Is this thy boy Leonoro?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: For fault of a better sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore heauen 'tis a sweete fac't child, me thinks he should show well in womans attire: and hee tooke her by the lilly white hand, and he laid her vpon a bed. Ile helpe thee to three crownes a weeke for him, and she can act well. Ha'st euer practis'd my pretty Ganimede?

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.p: No, nor neuer meane sir.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p:
Meane sir? No marry Captaine, there will neuer
be meane in his practise I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O finely taken; Sirha, Clarissimo, this fellow was an arrant Asse this fore-noone, afore he came to be an Antient.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But where's your Lieftenant Captaine?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Sownds man, hee's turnd swaggerer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ist possible?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Swaggerer by this light he; and is in the next roome writing a challenge to this tall Gentleman my Antient here.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What, mutinous in your owne company?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'fut man, who can bridle the asses valour?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: S'blood and any man thinke to bridle me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But what was the quarrell?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why sir, because I entertaind this Gentleman for my Antient, (being my deare friend and an excellent scholler) he takes pepper ith' nose and sneeses it out vpon my Antient; now sir (he being of an vncole-carrying spirit) fals foule on him, cals him gull openly; and euer since I am faine to drinke with 'em in two roomes, dare not let'em come together for my life, but with pen and inke-hornes, and so my Lieftenant is in the next chamber casting cold Inke vpon the (Enter Innocentio. )flame of his courage, to keepe him from the blot of cowardise, see where he comes with his challenge: good Clarissimo hold my Antient.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good Antient, forbeare in a Tauerne.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Reuenge noble Lieftenant, hast thou done it?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: S'light I thinke I haue pepperd him, but twas his owne seeking you know.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thats certaine.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Sownds my seeking sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Hold him Leonoro; and if it be possible, perswade him to heare the challenge from the enemies owne mouth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ile vndertake he shall Captaine: Good Antient let me entreate you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Well sir, because y'are a stranger to me, you shall doe more with me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Thanke you good ancient.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Reade fiery Lieftenant, reade boy, legibly.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Here it is sir: Signior Giouenelli, it is not ignorant vnto you, that euen now you crost me ouer the cocks-comb.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: I did so sir: I will not denie it I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good Ancient peace.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And that openly, or else it would neuer haue greeu'd me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: That openly was all indeede.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And moreouer, very vnreuerendly to call me gull, and asse to my face: And therefore, though I held it good discretion in me to winke at the blow, not seeing to take notice of it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Good discretion in deede.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Yet know that I will haue satisfaction from you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Well sir, and you shall.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Nay good Ancient heare him.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And desire you to send me word, whether you will maintaine it or no, hoping that you will not offer that discourtesie to doe me wrong, and stand to it when you haue done.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That were foule indeede.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And as for the words, in that you call'd me gull, and Asse to my face, resolue me by letter (for I do not thinke fit we should meete) first whether you spake any such words or no: and secondly by whom you meant'em. And it by me (as I thinke you durst not) confesse you are sorry for'hem: and if I haue offended you, I heartily aske you forgiuenesse. And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore heauen Ancient, this would haue tickled you, but good Leonoro, and thou bee'st a right Clarissimo, lets make'em friends, and drinke to one another: S'fut, we haue no wine here me thinks, where's this Aperner?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Haue you mended your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I Captaine, and if this please not your taste, either you or I cannot tast a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Sounds y'are very saucy sir, here Lieftenant, drink to thy Ancient, and voide mutinies with your officer, marshall law is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Is he content I should drinke to him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He is I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Why then Ancient good lucke t'ee.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.p: Let come Lieftenant, I pledge you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why so, now my company is cur'de againe, afore 'twas wounded. Come honorable Clarissimo, lets retire to our strength, taste a fresh carouse or two, and then march home with Musicke. Tapster, call vs in some Musicke.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I will sir.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Leonoro, Innocentio, Lionello, Fannio, with Musicke.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Strike vp Scrapers, honorable Clarissimo, and thy sweet Adonis, adieu, remember our deuice at the show soone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will not faile Captaine, farewell t'ee both: come Lionel, now let vs trie the truth of Madam Temperance, and see if shee attend vs.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: I hope by this time shee remembers her promise sir. Exeunt Leo. and Lio.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: How now Lieftenant, where's my Ancient?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Marry Captaine y'aue left him casting the reckoning ith' chimney.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Why then his purse and his stomacke wil be empty
together, and so I cashier him; let the scholler report at Padua, that Venice has other manner of learning belongs to it: what does his Continuum & Contiguum here? let'em goe to the Inke pot and beware of the wine pot.
Fill red cheek't Bacchus, let the Burdeux grape
Skip like la voltos in their swelling vaines.
Te dan, dan tidle, te dan de dan tidle didle, &c.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: O God Captaine that I could dance so.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: He tooke her by (strike vp fidlers) the lilly white hand and he laid her vpon the bedde. Oh what a spirit haue I now? I long to meete a Sergeant in this humor, I would but haue one whiffe at one of these same peuter button'd shoulder-clappers, to trie whether this chopping knife or their pestels were the better weapons. Here's a blade Boy, it was the old Dukes first predecessors; Ile tell thee what Lieftenant, this sword has dubd more Knights then thy knife has opened Oysters.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Ist possible Captaine, and me thinks it stands a little.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
No matter for that, your best mettald blades will stand soonest: so, now we haue attaind our Mansion house. At which Ile sing a verse shall breake the dores. O noble
Hercules, let no Stygian lake.
Te dan dan tidle, te dan de dan tidle didle, &c. Farewell scrapers, your reward now shall be that I will not cut your strings nor breake your fidles, via, away.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Come Captaine, lets enter, I long to see my Mistris, I warrant shee's a heauy Gentlewoman for your absence.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'fut she's an Asse, honour wooes me, preferment cals me, and I must lye pampred in a wenches lap, because shee dotes on me. Honour saies no, Lieftenant, Pugna pro patria, we must too't yfaith and seeke our portion amongst the scratcht faces.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo
sp.p: within .Mistris, Mistris, is he gone?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Whoe's that cals there?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: I heard no body.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: No? there was one cald Mistris: I say who cald Mistris, s'blood I hope I am not drunke.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: In truth sir I heard no body.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I tell thee I smelt a voice here in my entry, s'fut Ile make it smell worse and' cheare it againe.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: O me, hee'll draw vpon his owne shaddow in this humour, if it take the wall of him. Follow him Fannio, looke he doe no harme for God sake.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, helpe.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Name of God, what's there to doe? (Enter Quintil. and Lorenzo.)

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Good Captaine doe not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Sounds is hell broke loose? why Snaile, though you can sing songs and doe things Snaile, I must not allow yee to creepe into my wiues cole-house, what Snaile into my withdrawing chamber?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I beseech your Worship heare me speake.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O Snaile, this is a hard case; no roome serue your turne, but my wiues cole-house, and her other house of office annext to it? a priuy place for her selfe, and me sometimes, and will you vse it being a stranger? s'light how comes this about? vp sirha and call your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague of all disguises. Exit Fannio.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Alas poore Snaile, what didst thou make here?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I protest sir for no harme, my Mistris cald me in to sweepe her chimney, and because I did it not to her minde, shee made me doe pennance in her cole-house.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Search him Captaine and see, if he haue stolen nothing.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Kill me, hang me, if I haue.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Yes Snaile, and besides I heare complaints of you, y'are an old luxurious hummerer about wenches Snaile, does this become your grauity sir? Lieftenant, fetch me a cole-sacke, Ile put him in it and hang him vp for a signe.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I beseech your Worship be good to me.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Good Captaine pardon him, since he has done nothing but swept your chimney worse then my Mistris would haue it swept, he will doe it better another time.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well Snaile, at this Gentlemans request, (to whom I can denie nothing) I release you for this once, but let me take you no more thus I aduise you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Not while I liue good Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Hence, trudge you drudge, goe away.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague of all disguises. Exit Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: I haue look't about all the house for my Mistris sir, but I cannot finde her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Goe then, looke all about the towne for her too; come in Lieftenant, lets repose a little after our liquor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: DEare life, be resolute, that no respect
Heighted aboue the compasse of your loue,
Depresse the equall comforts it retaines;
For since it finds a firme consent in both,
And both our births and yeares agree so well,
If both our aged parents should refuse,
For any common obiect of the world,
To giue their hands to ours, let vs resolue
To liue together like our liues and soules.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.l: I am resolu'd my loue; and yet alas,
So much affection to my fathers will
Consorts the true desires I beare to you,
That I would haue no sparke of our loue seene,
Till his consent be ask'd, and so your fathers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: So runnes the mutuall current of my wish,
And with such staid and circumspect respects,
We may so serue and gouerne our desires,
That till fit obseruation of our fathers,
Preferre the motion to them; we may loue
Without their knowledge and the skill of any,
Saue only of my true friend Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.l: I wonder where he is.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not farre I know,
For in some place, he watcheth to preuent
The feared danger of your fathers presence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: SOunds stay for the loue of your honour sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague of all disguises Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What reason haue you to curse them? has not one of them kept you safe from the shame of the world, as much as a poore disguise might doe; but when your ridiculous feares will cast it off, euen while it is on, so running through the streets, that they rise all in an vprore after you; alas what is the poore disguise to blame sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well then fortune is to blame, or some thing; come as thou didst helpe to dawbe me, helpe to cleanse me, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let alone a while sir for Gods sake, Ile goe see whether the Captaine be gone from home or no.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Out vpon that course Angelo; I am frighted out of it, come enter my house, enter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What, will you enter your house sir afore you know who is in it: keepe your selfe close, and let me first enter and discouer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I know there is no body.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You cannot know it sir, I heard euen now that diuers of the Senate were determin'd to come and sit in Counsell there.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A tale, a very tale Angelo, enter for the loue of heauen, enter and vnsmother me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What shall I doe? my poore Master is berai'd, O that same faithlesse Lodowicke, that could drowne the swaggering Captaine no better in his drunkennesse; alas how should I salue this? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How now? whom doe I see? my daughter and a yonker together? passion of death, hell and damnation, what lecherous capricorne raignes this vnhappy day? old and yong in a predicament? O fie of filthy sinne and concupiscence, I will conceale my rage a while that it may breake forth in fury; Ile shift me presently Angelo, and goe fetch the Prouost.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O vnspeakable madnesse, will you for euer dishonour your daughter, and in her your selfe sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Talke not to me, out vpon this abhominable concupiscence, the pride of the flesh, this witchcraft of the Diuell: talke not to me, iustice cries out an't in the streets, and I will see it punish't, come good Angelo to helpe to shift me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ile follow you Sir instantly; Master, Master.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Angelo? what newes?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Miserable Master, cast downe your ladder, and come downe instantly.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Alas, why, Angelo is my father comming.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let vs not talke but come downe I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Deere life, farewell, wee'll shortly meete againe,
So parts the dying body from the soule;
As I depart from my Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.l: So enter frighted soules to the low world,
As my poore spirit vpon this soddaine doubt,
What may succeede this danger.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come away, you'll be whipt anone for your amourosity, hast for shame hast, &c.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Once more and euer, fare my deere life well.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Leaue your amorous congeis & get you in Dame;
sir you and I will talke as 'twere betwixt the pales, now, get you and shift you of this sute presently.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Shift me Angelo? why man?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Aske me no questions, but goe home and shift you presently, and when I haue done a little businesse here within, Ile come and tell you my deuice: there hath more chanc't then you are aware of, and then I can stand to tell you; away therefore presently goe home and shift you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Very good sir, I will be ruld by you, and after learne the misteries. Exit Aurel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now will I let the little squire shift and cleanse himselfe without me, that he may be longer about fetching the Prouost, and in the meane time will I take my Masters sute (of which the little squire tooke note) and put it on my sweet heart Francischina, who shall presently come and supply my Masters place, with his Mistris; for the little squire amaz'd with his late affrights and this suddaine offencefull spectacle of his daughter, tooke no certaine note who it was that accosted her; for if he had, he would haue blam'd me for my Master, only the colour of his garment sticks in his fancie, which when he shall still see where he left it, he will still imagine the same person weares it, and thus shall his daughters honour and my Masters be preseru'd with the finest sugar of inuention. And when the little squire discouers my sweet heart, shee shall sweare, shee so disguised her selfe, to follow him, for her loue to him; ha, ha ha, O the wit of man when it has the winde of a woman. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Lodouico and Lucretia, with Rapiers fighting.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: HOld, hold, I pre thee hold; I yeeld my rapier,
Let my submission, my presumption salue.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Ignoble Lodwicke, should I take thy life,
It were amends too little for the wrong.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O the precious heauens:
How was I gul'd? haud, hide thy selfe for shame.
And henceforth haue an eye before thy fingers.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Well do not ieast it out, for I protest
If this disguise, which my inhumane fate
Puts on my proper sexe, be by thy meanes
Seene through, by any other then thy selfe,
The quarrell twixt vs shall be more then mortall.
And thy dishonour to a friendlesse stranger
(Exild his natiue countrey, to remaine
Thrall to the mercy of such vnknowne maids
As fortune makes the rulers of my life)
Shall spread it selfe beyond my misery,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, mixe not cause of mirth with passion,
Do me the grace t'vnfold thy name and state,
And tell me what my whole estate may doe,
To salue this wrong vnwittingly I did thee?
And set the plantife thoughts of thy hard fate
In such peace, as my friendship may procure:
And if I faile thee, let Ioue fayle my soule,
When most this earth makes it need help of heauen.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: In the more then temper my late rage
And show your vertues perfectly deriu'd
From the Venetian noblesse; for my name
It is Lucretio, which to fit this habit
I turn'd Lucretia: the rest that rests
To be related of my true estate,
Ile tell some other time: least now your presence
Might dumbly tell it (if it should be seene)
To all the world, or else make it suspect
My femall life of lightnesse: then with thanks
And vow of all true friendship, for th'amends
Your kindnesse makes me, take your sword againe,
And with it while I liue the power of mine
In any honor'd vse shall commaund.
Then till we meete, and may laugh at this error,
Ile once more trie the free peace of my chamber. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do so sweet friend: a plague of Gingerly?
Where is that stale and fulsome Gingerly,
She brought me to a fury, Ile be sworne
Rather then man or woman: a flat beating:
I found her suppos'd mistresse fast asleepe,
Put her to the touchstone, and she prou' a man.
He wak't, and with a more then manly spirit
Flew in my face, and gaue me such a dash
In steed of kissing, of these licorish lips
That still my teeth within them bled I sweare He spits.
Gengerly, Gingerly, a plague a you. He spits againe.
But now how does my louers on the Tarrasse?

div.stage: Enter Aurelio with Angelo, shifting his Apparell.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: HOld, take my dublet too, my hat and all, and quickly hie thee to thy sweete.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: S'ounds, see sir see, your proper Sentinell, that when you needed him, gaue you a slip.

sp.speaker: Anr.
sp.p: Friend Lodouico, by my life, well welcome to this my fathers backeside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well sir, well, I would I had kist almost your fathers backeside so I had neuer knowne it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A my life he faints extremely, he left you euen now to purchase him the amorous enteruiew of your fayre cuze Lucretia that lies heere.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Gods me, sweete friend, would'st thou vse such a slight to any one that lay within my walke? who was thy meane to her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I lay my life, tame madam Temperance, the notorious Pandar.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: S'fut friend, wat a notorious ouersight was that? and what a violent iniury vnto thy friend?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p:
A plague vpon you both, you scuruy hinde, haue
you no gull but me to whet your wit vpon?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My friend a priuie louer? I'de haue sworne
Loue might spend all his shafts at butterflies
As well as at his bosome.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Twas your fault then,
For I haue noted a most faithfull league
Betwixt him and his barber now of late,
And all the world may see, he does not leaue
One haire on his smooth chinn, as who should say,
His haplesse loue was gone against the hayre.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: S'bloud & these rogues knew how I was deceiu'd,
They'd stout me into motley, by this light.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well sir, I euer thought y'ad the best wit
Of any man in Venice next mine owne,
But now Ile lay the bucklers at your feete,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A poxe vpon thee, tame your bald hewed tongue,
Or by the Lord of heauen Ile pull it out.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O my sweet friend, come Ile know more of this,
And tell thee all our fortune, hence good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O, if this man had patience to his braine,
A man might load him till he smart againe. Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Patience worthy friend, hee knowes you loue him for his knauish wit. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: THou shalt not stay sweet Temperance, tell vs the manner of our warre and wee'll leaue thee presently.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p:
Why that perl's man Lodowicke, according to your appointment was iumpe at three with mee, iust, beene full at your hower; Muffled as I wild you, ee'ne your fashion and your very leg for all the earth, and followed me in so gingerly, that by my troth I must needs say, he was worthy the pleasuring; but in what a taking was I when I perceiued
his voyce? & when I saw my mistresse & he together by the eares?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What did thy mistesse fight with him?

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: O king a heauen, she ranne vpon his naked weapon the most finely that euer liu'd, and I ran away in a swoone for feare.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Has she a good courage?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: It seemes she is too honest for our companies, a little more good Temperance.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: And when he saw me, he call'd me punke, and pandor, and doxie, & the vilest nicknames as if I had ben an arrand naughty-packe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter Temperance, hee's knowne and thou art knowne.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: I thanke heauen for it, and ther's all indeed, I can stay no longer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Farewell honest Temperance: how was it possible, Lodouico should fit all these circumstances without the confederacy and trechery of this beldam? well Lodouico must satisfie this doubt when I see him.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: That will be at the May night shew at Signior Honorios.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I would not meet him there, I shall offend him, but there I must needs be, and haue thee disguis'd like a woman.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Me sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No remedy, the Captain Quintilliano and I haue deuis'd it to gull his Lieutenant: for thou shalt dance with him, we will thrust him vpon thee, and then for his courting and gifts, which we will tell him he must win thee withall, I hope thou wilt haue wit enough to receiue the tone, and pay him againe with the tother, come Lionell let me see how naturally thou canst play the woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Better then you thinke for.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: COme Lieutenant, this nap has set a nap of sobriety vpon our braines, now lets sit heere & consult, what course were best for vs to take in this dangerous mansion of mans life.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: I am for you yfaith Captaine & you go to consult once.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I know it Lieutenant, say then what think'st thou? we talk't of employment, of action, of honor, of a company & so forth.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Did we so Captaine?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Did we so Asse? S'fut, wert thou drunke afore thou went'st to the tauerne, that thou hast now forgotten it?

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Crie you mercy good Captaine, I remember I am your Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well sir, and so thou shalt be called stil, and I Captaine, though we neuer leade other company then a sort of quart pots.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Shall we Captaine, byth masse then lets neuer haue other company in deed.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why now th'art wise, and hast a minde transform'd with maine right, and to confirme thee, I will compare the noble seruice of a feast with the honourable seruice of the field, and then put on thy hand to which thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Thanke you good Captaine, but do you thinke that warre is naught sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Exceeding naught.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Why then sir take heede what you say, for 'tis dangerous speaking against any thing that is naught, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou saist wisely Lieutenant, I will not then vse the word naught, nor speake ill of eyther, but compare them both, and choose the better.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Take heede then good Captaine, there be some prickear'd intelligencers conuaid into some wall or other about vs.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: If there were I care not, for to say true, the first modell of a battell was taken from a banquet. And first touching the offices of both: for the generall of the field, there is the master of the feast, for the Lieutenant Generall, the mistresse, for the Sergeant Maior, the Steward, for the Gentleman vsher, the Marshall, for master oth' Ordinance the Sewer, and all other officers.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Yet y'are reasonable well Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then for the preparation, as in a field is all kinde of artillery, your Cannon, your Demicannon, Culuerings, falkons, Sacres, minions, & such goodly ornaments of a field, I speake no hurt of em thou seest, Ile haue nothing to do do with 'am.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Hold you still there Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Besides other munition of powder and shot, and so for
the feast, you haue your Court, cubbords planted with flagons, cannes, cups, beakers, bowles, goblets, basens and ewers: And more glorious shew I wisse then the tother, and yet I speake no hurt of the other.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: No Ile be sworne Captaine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Besides your munition of manchet, napery plats, spoons, glasses and so forth; Then for your kitchen artillerie, there shall you see all your brasse peeces mounted in order, as your beefe-pots, your chaldrons, your kettles, chafingdishes, ladies, spits, a more edifying spectacle then your Cannon & Culuering, and yet I speake no hurt of them neither.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: No Captaine, thus farre, I goe wee.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then sir, as in the field the drumme, so to the feast the dresser giues the Alarme, Ran tan tara, tan tan tantara tan.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: O how it stirres my stomacke?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: First then sets forward a wing of light horse, as sallads, brothes, sauces, flew'd meats, and other kickshores, and they giue a charge, then do the battell ioyne Captaine Capon in white-brith, Lieutenant calues head.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Thats my place.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Ancient Surloigne, a man of a goodly presence, and full of expectation, as you ancient ought to bee, then haue you Sergeant Piemeat, Corporall Conny, Lanceprizado Larke, Gentlemen, Panbakex, & all the species of a company.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Would we might fall to the fight once.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why now growes the fight hot man, now shall you see many a tall piece of beefe, many a tough capon go downe, and hee'r's the triall of a mans stomacke, all the while the Artillery playes on both hands, the Canons lay about them, the flagons go off, thicke and threefold, and many a tall man goes halting off, some quite ouerthrowne both horse and foote.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: O my heart bleeds.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
That is, thy teeth water. In conclusion, as the remnant of the feast, (I meane such dishes as scap't the fury of the fight) if they be seruiceable, are reseru'd to furnish out another day if they be maim'd or spoyld, they are sent abroad to relieue prisons and hospitals. So the remainder of the fight, if they be seruiceable, they are reseru'd to supply a second field, for the
fragments of the fight, viz. the maimd soldiers, they are sent likewise to furnish prisons and hospitals, how sayest thou now Lieutenant, shall we to the feast, or to the fight?

sp.speaker: Inn.
sp.p: No fighting good Captain, to the feast for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Tha'rt a my mind right, and so will we presently march on to the sacke of the Emperours head, then to the May-night feast, and shew at Signior Honorios, and there will be a wench there boy, a delicate yong morsell, a kinswoman of Signior Honorios, and her fathers only child, he a mighty rich Clarissimo, and her shalt thou court, winne her and weare her, thou hast wit at will.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: But shall that wench be her fathers sonne and heire Captaine?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Shee shall be his heire, a mine honesty.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: But shall not my Mistris your wife bee at that show?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Shee shall, and we could finde her; Fannio has beene abroade this houre to seeke her: the Asse is stept into some corner or other mourning for my absence. (Enter Angelo and Francischina in disguise. )See who comes here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come Cuze, march faire, me thinks thou becom'st a Page excellent naturally, cheere vp thy heart wench. Kisse her.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Fie for shame kisse in the streets?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why not? truth seekes no corners, and 'twas a true loues kisse, and so is this.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Ware riot, do'st thou marke Lieftenant?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Gods pitty, my husband. Exeunt Franc. Ang.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: What were these Captaine?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Vpon my life the hindermost of them, is a wench in mans attire, didst thou not marke besides his slabbering about her, her bigge thighs and her splay feete.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: By the meskin me thought they were so indeede.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'life, the hungry knaue her squire, could not hold in the open streets.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: What should shee be?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: The Doxie was muffeld in her cloake, I had but a glimpse of her; but s'light I will know her, shee passes not so, come wee'll follow. Ile beate the Rogue and take away's whore from him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: COme courage Cuze, wee haue sail'd the man of Warre out of sight, and here wee must put into harbour. Hist, hawe Amila?

sp.speaker: Amil.
sp.p: O welcome good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Here take in, goe, get vp lightly, away, take heed you slip not Cuze, remember y'are short heel'd.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Hold fast for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay hold you fast, you'll shame vs all else; so Ioue receiue thy soule: I take away the ladder: Now till you haue deceiued the Prouost, farewell, remember your lesson Cuze. Exit.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: I warrant you. (Enter Quintil. and Innocentio)

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: How vnhappily did we misse 'em? they slipt into some vaulting house, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Faith it's good we mist'em, she was some stale punke I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Twenty to one shee is some honest mans wife of the Parish that steales abroade for a trimming, while he sits secure at home, little knowing, God knowes, what hangs ouer his head; the poore Cuckold esteeming her the most vertuous wife in the world. And shoude one tell him, he had seene her drest like a Page following a knaue thus, Ile lay my life he would not beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Why no Captaine, wiues take all the faith from their husbands. And that makes 'em doe so many good workes as they doe.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Mercy for that yfaith Lieftenant, stand close. (Enter Fannio and Giacono)

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: My Mistris in mans apparell saist thou?

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Thy Mistris in mans apparell I assure thee, and attended by Angelo.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Would to heauen I had seene her, canst tell whither shee went.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Full butt into Lorenzoes house, and if thou knewst him, thou know'st wherefore, an ill-fauourd trimming is her errand.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p:
'Tis very well, shee trims my Captaine prettily, in the
meane time his head paies for all, and yet alas poore hornestocke, he thinks her to haue no fault, but her too much dotage vpon him, well my conscience will not let me keepe her counsaile, he shall know on't.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Why man if both of vs should tell him her fault he will not beleeue vs.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: No, nor if he had seene it with his owne owne eyes I thinke, I shal neuer forget how the profound Cockatrice hung on his sleeue to day, and he shoude not from her sight, shee'd follow him into the warres, one day should make an end of both their loues and liues, and then to see him the wittall, my Captaine began to stroote, and batle the pride of his merits that so heightned her affection.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: True, and how the foppasty his Lieftenant, stept in to perswade with her, to take it patiently, for friends must part, we came not all together, and we must not goe all together.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Well, 'twill not be for any man to follow him, if this were knowne once.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Lord how all the boyes in the towne would flocke about him as he walks the streets, as 'twere about a bagge-pipe, and hoote the poore Cuckold out of his hornecase.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Well, and I were worthy to giue him counsaile, he should e'ne faire and well hang himselfe.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: No, no, keepe it from him, and say thou found'st her at a womans labour.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: A plague of her labour, the Captaines browes sweate while shee labours.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: If I were in thy case, I should laugh out right when I saw him.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: That dare not I doe, but as often as he turnes his backe to me, I shall be here V with him thats certaine: or when I follow him and his cheating stocke Innocentio, in the streets, I shall imagine still I am driuing an Oxe and an Asse before me, and cry phtroh, ho, ptrough.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: S'light Captaine take this and take all.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p:
Not a word for the world, for if we should take notice of his words the slaue would denie all, leaue it to me to sift it in priuate. Now sir, what newes with you? where's your Mistris,
that you range thus at your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: In health sir I trust.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come forward you rogue you: come forward, whither creepe you behinde so? where's your Mistris sir?

sp.speaker: Fann
sp.p: At a poore womans labour sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Very well sir, come Lieftenant, goe you afore, and doe you follow him sir.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: What afore my Captaine sir: you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore you rogue, afore. Exeunt

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Honorio, Lorenzo, Gasparo and Angelo.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: SIgnior Lorenzo, and Gasparo, y'are very welcome, we shall haue good company and sport to entertaine you ere long I hope, shall we not Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Yes sir, I haue enuited all you commanded me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This is the honest man indeede, that tooke the paines to come for me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And for me also.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No paines but pleasure sir, I was glad I had such good meanes to be knowne to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nay, I haue knowne you before, to be the seruant of Signior Honorio here, I take it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Not my seruant Signior Lorenzo, but my sonnes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O, your sonne Aurelios seruant? beleeue me you or your sonne (in mine opinion, though I say it before him) made good choice of him: for he hath a good honest face, and to a man of iudgement (I tell you) that's as good as a good surety for him. I will be better acquainted with you sir, pray you giue me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Both my hand and heart sir, shall be euer at your seruice.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thanks my good friend, Ile make thee laugh anone Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I thanke your Worship, you haue done so often.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: A notable wagge Signior Gasparo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: How curiously Lorenzo thinks he carries the matter?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How now Gentlemen, ist a merry secret, that you smile so?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No secret Signior Lorenzo, but a merry conceipt we were thinking on, to furnish our show anone, if it had beene thought on in time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What was that I pray?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Marry sir, we had good sport to day with Snayle the chimney-sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Had you so sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: That euer was.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Lord that I had beene amongst you, but what more of him sir?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Marry sir, we were thinking how we might merrily deceaue our company that is to come, if we could haue gotten him some magnificoes sute of the Citty, whom for his little stature and leane face he might resemble, that in that habit he might haue stolen some kinde fauours from the Ladies, to make him amends and please him for the anger we put him in.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: It would haue made excellent merriment.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You are his best Master sir, and if it please you to send me for him by some token, Ile goe for him; otherwise he will not come to these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Shall he come Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: If you please sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Why then hearke thee Angelo; not for the world.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Thinke you me such an Asse sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Shall he haue one of my little brothers suites, and come in amongst the Dames for him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: If you could, it would fit him exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Much; now laugh Angelo: what Gentleman was that I spi'd aloft with my daughter think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know not sir; I beseech your Worship who was it?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Franke, in mans apparell Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We cannot inuent a token, for my loue Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O excellent.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We will hit it anone Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: At your leasure sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The swaggerer her husband, had note of it by his Page, and yet the same Page hath perswaded him, since that 'twas but a gullery.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: 'Tis a notable cracke; and his Master hath such a pure beleefe in his wife, that hee's apt to beleeue any good of her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: True Angelo, enough for this time; thou shalt make as if thou went'st for Snaile, and returne without him, saying thou canst not finde him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Agreed sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, we haue deuis'd a wile to bring Snaile amongst vs, and I haue giuen Angelo order for a sute for him, that is my little brothers, and him he shall counterfeit; goe Angelo seeke him out.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will sir. Exit Ang.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Thanke you for this good Signior Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: It will quicken the company well. Enter Aemilia, Lionell, Francischina and another woman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: For their sakes and yours, I haue done it Gentlemen; and see the faire flocke come vpon vs.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Welcome faire Ladies, but especially you Lady, that are so meere a stranger, Signior Lorenzo you know yong Leonoro?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Very well sir, a gallant sparke.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And I thinke you know his father.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Know him? I faith sir there was a reueller, I shall neuer see man doe his lofty tricks like him while I liue.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman is his Neice sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: His Neice? shee shall doe her selfe wrong not to be acquainted with her deere vnkles companion: Kisse her.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: You know not this Gentlewoman sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Not very well sir indeede, but entertainement must be giuen, mercy Franke for thy mans apparell, a plague of all
swaggering husbands. Nay I must forth yfaith, Signior Honorio, this is for your sake, am I not a kinde helpe to your entertainement?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: An exceeding kinde one sir, and I exceedingly thanke you. (Enter Messenger.)

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: The maskers are come sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Doe you and your fellowes attend them in.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: We will sir. Exit Mess.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Sit gentle Ladies till the maskers raise you to dance.

div.stage: Enter Aurelio, Leonoro, Quintiliano, and Innocentio, in a maske dancing.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: WElcome Gallants, O the roome's too scant, a hall Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: See how womanly my Boy lookes Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Twill be rare sport; Lieftenant, that sweet wench in the brancht gowne is the heire I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Gods me, Ile to her and kisse her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O no, you must not vnmaske.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: No, no, Ile kisse her with my maske and all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No Lieftenant, take her and court her first, and then kisse her.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: To her slaue.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: There's thy wife too, Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: True, little knowes shee I am so neere her; Ile single her out, and trie what entertainement a stranger may finde with her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Doe so, and wee'll take vp the tother. (Enter Angelo.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I can by no meanes finde Snaile sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: The worse lucke, but what remedy?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Gramercy Angelo; but Signior Lorenzo, mee thinks I misse one flower in this femall garland.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Whos's that?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Your Neice Lucretia,

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: By my soule 'tis true; whats the reason Angelo Lucretia is not here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know no reason but her owne will sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Ther's somewhat in it certaine. They dance againe.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Did you see the play to day I pray?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: No, but I see the foole in it here.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Doe you so forsooth? where is he pray?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Not farre from you sir, but we must not point at any body here.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Thats true indeede, cry mercy forsooth, doe you know me through my maske?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Not I sir, shee must haue better skill in bak't meats then I, that can discerne a woodcocke through the crust.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Thats true indeede, but yet I thought I'de try you. (Enter Lodouico.) They dance.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What Nephew Lodwicke, I thought you had beene one of the maskers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I vse no masking sir with my friends.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No signior Lodowick, but y'are a very truant in your schoole of friendship, that come so late to your friends.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Somewhat has crost him sure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Somewhat shall crosse him; Lodouico let me speake with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are the man sir, I can scarse say the Gentleman, for you haue done a wrong the credit of a Gentleman cannot answere.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Would I might see his face, that durst say so much.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Obserue him well, he shoes his face that will proue it when thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How now Leonoro, you forget your selfe too much, to grow outragious in this company.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Aurelio, doe not wrong me, and your selfe, I vndertake your quarrell, this man hath dishonord your Kinswoman Lucretia, whom (if I might) I intended to marry.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Some error makes you mistake Leonoro, I assure my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What interruption of our sport is this gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Are not my Nephew and Leonoro friends?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He charges me with dishonoring his mistris Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Birlady Lodouico, the charge touches you deeply, you must answere it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I only desire I may sir, and then will referre me to your censures.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well Nephew, well; will you neuer leaue this your haunt of fornication? I schoole him, and doe all I can, but all is lost.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good Vnkle giue me leaue to answere my other accuser, and then Ile descend, and speake of your fornication, as the last branch of my diuision.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Very well, be briefe.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will sir; The ground vpon which this man builds his false imagination, is his sight of me at Honorios backe gate, since dinner, where muffled in my cloke, kinde Madam Temperance, the attendant of Lucretia, from the Tarrasse, wafted me to her with her hand; taking me (as now I vnderstand) for this honest Gentleman, I not knowing what vse shee had to put me to, obaid the attraction of her signall, as gingerly as shee bad me. (A plague vpon her gingerly) till shee lockt me into Lucretias chamber, where Lucretia lying asleepe on her bed, I thought it rudenesse to wake her; and (imagining when shee wak't shee had something to say to me) attended her leasure at my ease, and lay downe softly by her; when (hauing chaster and simpler thoughts then Leonoro imagines) because he measures my wast by his owne) in the very coldnesse and dulnesse of my spirit, I fell sodainly a-sleepe. In which my fancy presented me with the strangest dreame, that euer yet possest me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Pray God you did but dreame Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You shall know that by knowing the euent of it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Goe to, pray let vs heare it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Me thought Lucretia and I were at mawe, a game Vnkle that you can well skill of.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well sir I can so.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You will the more muse at my fortune; or my ouersights. For my game stood, me thought, vpon my last two tricks, when I made sure of the set, and yet lost it, hauing the varlet and the fiue finger to make two tricks.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How had that beene possible?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: That had beene no misfortune sure but plaine ouersight.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: But what was the reason you thought you lost it sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You shall heare; shee had in her hand the Ace of Hearts, me thought, and a Coate-carde, shee led the bord with her coate, I plaid the varlet, and tooke vp her coate, and meaning to lay my fiue finger vpon her Ace of hearts, vp start a quite contrary card; vp shee rises withall, takes me a dash a the mouth, drew a rapier he had lay by him, and out of dores we went together by the eares.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: A rapier he had lay by him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What a shee turned to a he? do'st thou not dreame all this while Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No nor that time neither, though I pretended it; let him be fetcht, I warrant you he will show as good cards as the best on you, to proue him an heir Male, if he be the eldest child of his father.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: This is exceeding strange: goe Angelo, fetch her and her hand-maide.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will sir, if her valure be not too hot for my fingers. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Could such a disguise be made good all this while without my knowledge? to say truth, shee was a stranger to me, her father being a Sicilian: fled thence for a disausterous act, and comming hither grew kindly acquainted with me, and called me brother. At his death committing his supposed daughter to my care and protection, till she were restor'd to her estate in her natiue Country.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Was he in hope of it?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He was, and in neere possibility of it himselfe, had he liu'd but little longer. (Enter Angelo and Lucretia.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Here's the Gentlewoman you talkt of sir, nay you must come forward too graue Mistris Temperance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now sir? who wants gentility now I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Who haue we here?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Stand not amaz'd, nor disparage him: you see sir, this habit truly doth sute my sexe, howsoeuer my hard fortunes haue made me a while reiect it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What hard fortunes?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Those you know of my father sir: who feard my following of him in my natiue likenesse, to the hauen, where he by stealth embarqu't vs, and would haue discouer'd him, his offence being the slaughter of a Gentleman, that would haue slaine him.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: But did you not tell me you were betroth'd before this misfortune hapned, to a yong Gentleman of Sicily, call'd Theagines?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I told you I was betroth'd to one Theagine, not Theagines, who indeed was a woman,

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: And yet whosoeuer had seene that Theagine since might haue taken him for a man.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Do you know her Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: L●o.
sp.p: It seemes you will not know her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Hearke how my boy plaies the knaue with her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: A noble rogue, S'fut Lieutenant, wilt thou suffer thy nose to be wipt of this great heire?

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: S'light sir you are no handkercher are you?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Pre thee forbeare, more happy then vnlookt for Is this deere accident: adopted and noble father, this is the Gentlewoman to whom I told you I was betroth'd, the happy newes she had to relate to me, made her a traueller, the more search of her passage made her a Page, and her good fortune obtaind her— this honest Gentleman to her Master, who I thanke him, being (as he supposed me) lou'd me, accept vs both for your children.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Most gladly and with no lesse care, then mine owne protect you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'fut, how now Leonora? new fireworkes?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: New sir, who wants gentility? this is a gentlemanly part of you to keepe a wench in a Pages furniture?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It was more then I knew Sir, but this shall be a warning to me while I liue, how I iudge of the instrument by the case againe.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nay it is you friend Lodouico that are most to blame, that holding the whole feminine sexe in such contempt, would yet play the pickpurse, and steale a poore maids maidenhead out of her pocket sleeping.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Twas but to cousen mee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And to be before me in loue.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, ieast not at me sweete Gentles, I v'sd plaine and mannerly dealing, I neither v'sd the brokage of any, as you know who did Leonoro, nor the help of a ladder to creep in at a wenches chamber window (as you know who did Aurelio.) Nor did I case my selfe in buckrame, and crie chimney sweepe (where are you vncle?) but I was train'd to it by this honest matron here.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: Meddle not with me sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: I am beholding to her, she was loth to haue me leade apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Looke that you keepe promise with me Ladie, when will thy husband be from home?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not so soone as I would wish him, but whensoeuer you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I very kindly thanke you Lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Gods me, I tooke you for Signior Placentia.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: S'fut, thou liest in thy throte, thou knewst me as well as my selfe.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: What, Signior Quintilian, and friend Innocentio? I look't not for you here, & y'are much the better welcome.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: Thanks dad Honorio, and liues my little squire? when shall I see thee at my house lad?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A plague a your house, I was there too lately.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: See Lordings, her's two will not let go till they haue your consents to be made surer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By my soule, and because old Gasparo heere has bene so cold in his loue sute, if she be better pleas'd with Aurelio, and his father with her, heauen giue abundance of good with him.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: So you stand not too much vpon goods, I say, Amen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Faith vse him as your sonne and heire, and I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: So will I of mine honour, are you agreed youths?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: And most humbly gratulate your high fauors.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Faith & Ioue giue 'em ioy together for my part.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yet is heere another nayle to be driuen, heer's a vertuous Matron, Madam Temperance, that is able to doe much good in a commonwealth, a woman of good parts, sels complexionn helpes maids to seruices, restores maidenheads, brings women to bed, and men to their bedsides.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: By my faith, but saue votre grace sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Hath drinks for loue, and giues the diet.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: Birladie, and thats not amisse for you sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: For me, with a plague tee?

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: No nor for any man thats not sound I meane sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: S'fut masters these be good parts in the old wench, wilt thou haue her Lieutenant? sheele be a good stay to the rest of thy liuing, the gallants will all honour thee at thy house I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Fore God Captaine I care not if I haue.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: Well yong Gentleman, perhaps it should not be the worst for you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why law, thy vertues haue own her at first sight, shee shall not come to thee emptie, for Ile promise thee that Ile make her able to bid any Gentleman welcome to a peece of mutton and rabbet at all times.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Birladie, a good Ordinarie.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thow't visit sometimes Dad.

sp.speaker: Lor
sp.p: That I will yfaith boy in authority wise.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Why then strike hands, and if the rest be pleas'd,
Let all hands strike as these haue strucke afore,
And with round Ecchoes make the welken rore. Exeunt.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
